reviews.review_title: Gene Wilder was born on June 11th, 1933
reviews.content: I definitely had a different impression of this film, when I originally saw it as a kid, as opposed to seeing it today in the 21st century. It however, has not lost its charm or enjoyment, just because I'm an adult now. It just allows me to have two unique perspectives, that easily allow me to put myself into a 1971 frame of mind. It is felt, especially in relation to Willy's (Gene Wilder's), main introduction, when he makes his first appearance in the movie. It's kind of a lackluster moment when you look at it as an older viewer. It is so much bigger an entrance when seeing it as a kid. You notice as an adult that Gene handles the whole situation great, by making it look more like a businessman doing business. We don't really care though. We've been inundated with delicious, chocolate imagery up to this point, that we just want to get into the factory. It doesn't matter what age you are. You still feel the same.Five golden tickets are placed into random Wonka chocolate bars. Whoever finds the golden tickets receives a free tour of Wonka's chocolate factory. Charlie (Peter Ostrum), our main character, finds the last golden ticket. Along with his grandfather Joe (Jack Albertson), they go to meet Willy Wonka, the other four ticket winners and get the grand tour of the famed chocolate factory. From here you are taken into a magical world with chocolate streams and candy flowers. But, there are other strange things afoot in this factory. There is a weird mood felt all through the film. It is driven by the eccentric energy of Gene Wilder. The film was nominated for an Academy Award for music. It has many familiar tunes, especially the haunting Oompa-Loompa song, which always reminds us, that temptation sometimes can be a person's undoing. The special effects, art direction and entertainment value is quite good in this Paramount Pictures release. It is one, that kids from the 1970s and ever since can enjoy. It also is a wonderful film for those children to see, when they get older too. Plus, chocolate is great.8.0 (B- MyGrade) = 8 IMDB.

I've watched this movie many times and it never gets old. I have 3 boys - they are all grown up now with kids of their own. The remember this movie and remember the messages the ooompa-loompas gave to them. All of the messages got thru to them -every time they watched it. It should be shown to all kids now days - the messages and life lessons are still true today and they were when this movie came out.

Like millions of children I loved this magical film. It is a joy for the young and young and heart. I still enjoy it even as I am fast approaching middle age. It is a wonderful family film. Everything about it is sheer joy from the beautiful songs (especially Pure Imagination, if that song doesn't touch your heart you have none) to the candy garden in the factory. Gene Wilder is wonderful as the magical candyman (Robin Williams could have played this part, I don't know why I am thinking this). Peter Ostrum only made this one film and never acted again,which is a shame because he is wonderfully sweet as Charlie. Jack Albertson was the consummate character actor. He is wonderful as Grandpa Joe. This movie is still as wonderful and good today as in 1971 and that says a lot. BY the way, there is sort of an inside joke in the film most people don't catch. There is a scene where they are talking about a Wonka ticket being found and then the story is a hoax. The picture of the hoaxer on the newspaper is a picture of Martin Bormann. He was one of Hitler's henchmen. He disappeared from Berlin at the end of WWII and was never seen again. By the way, the scene where Grandpa Joe and Charlie drink those fizzy drinks and rise up to the ceiling and then come back down by belching was all wrong, they should have farted instead, it would have been funnier!

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is the very definition of a small (and extremely questionable) idea overwhelmed by huge production, and very bad production at that.  Horrendous performances abound, none worse than Jack Albertson.  The dialog makes one's skin crawl.  The production design, sets and costumes are ghastly.  When I see time and again how many people dote on this film, it reinforces the realization that good taste is a very rare commodity.

reviews.review_title: A Lesson For Kids And Adults
reviews.content: The beauty about Willy Wonka is how it teaches kids not to be gluttonous, slothful, arrogant, or narcissistic, but also how it teaches parents not to cave to the demands of their children, and not to let television or food become the babysitter. It also teaches children how even if you do make mistakes, you can be redeemed through selflessness in the future.Timeless morals for a timeless movie.

Despite being disowned by Roald Dahl, I would consider this movie a considerable success. This was an adaptation that would live or die on the casting of the lead role, and in Gene Wilder they couldn't have done much better. Wilder's perfect balance of eccentricity, humour and mystery elevates the film above and beyond gentle fiction and provides a very fitting dose of darkness.The rest of the cast is also pretty strong, particularly Julie Dawn Cole as the bratty Veruca Salt. Peter Ostrum looks and sounds just right as Charlie, although the character is somewhat overshadowed by Wilder's mesmerising Wonka. Paris Themman is quite poor as Mike Teevee but I would largely put that down to the character being so badly written by Dahl. I would have been perfectly happy for them to write Teevee out of the script completely.The music is a huge success, containing some iconic songs that are still fresh almost 50 years later. Leslie Bricusse deserves an awful lot of credit for what he did with this soundtrack. Pure Imagination is particularly beautiful and is probably my enduring memory of this movie.The major weak point of the film is how cheap some of it looks. The factory looks like just that- a factory. It has no magic, no beauty and no charm. The chocolate river looks like contaminated water and the 'TV particles' effect stands as one of the laziest pieces of CGI I've ever seen.There are also plenty of flaws in the story that bother me. It seems perfectly reasonable for the destitute Charlie to sell the everlasting gobstopper to Slugworth, and had he done so I don't think it would tarnish his character. On the flip side, the wealthy Veruca could have turned down the offer merely because the money wasn't meaningful enough for it to be worth effort. She'd still be a bad person either way. Wonka really should have considered this financial relativism before devising his bizarre inheritance plan. Also, what if only adults had won tickets? Or if all the children were non-English speaking? Besides this, most of the logistical flaws are Dahl's doing (seriously, a kid who lives a few hundred yards from the factory finds a Golden Ticket at the local shop?) and the writers can't do much about it.Despite a few flaws, this is a great family film with a captivating lead performance from Gene Wilder. It is certainly not as polished as Tim Burton's remake but it has an awful lot more charm and character.

reviews.review_title: "You look like you were born to be a Wonkarer"
reviews.content:
So says Aubrey Woods as the world's most psychologically disturbing sweet shop owner.While Roald Dahl is renowned as a fine children's book writer, his screenplay abilities are often overlooked. Possibly the best - certainly one of the most underrated - James Bond films has his name as screenwriter, (You Only Live Twice) and this movie is equally delightful and grand in scale.
The first half of the film is a curiously old-fashioned, child-centred piece, where a whole nation of adults alter their lifestyles for a chance to win a "Golden Ticket". "Class dismissed" calls one teacher as he rushes out to buy a potentially winning chocolate bar. Another scene sees a bed-ridden cripple, perhaps slightly offensively, get out of bed and dance after winning a ticket. Good-natured yet packed with racial stereotypes (including greedy Germans, arrogant Americans and Charlie's grandparents who are, for some reason, Jewish) the film can be saccharine-coated but that is all saved by one man: Gene Wilder.Charlie, meanwhile, is the kind of selfless martyr that really deserves a slap, if only to dislodge his halo. (And he's a litter-dropper, too: look at the scene where he inevitably finds the final ticket. Come to that, he's a thief: he finds money yet doesn't hand it in to the police). Things notably improve in the second half, if only the quality of the songs. This is the half where we go from drab to ultra-imaginative, with Wilder's enigmatic  if disturbingly tactile  Wonka steals the film. His total sense of disattachment at the various downfalls of the children adds an interesting depth to the character; and a refreshing counterpoint to the somewhat self-righteous attitudes of Charlie, his grandfather and the Oompa-Loompas.Highlights of Wonka's chocolate factory include the "Repulsion" style coathangers, candy packed with gelagnite and a man-sized teleporting chocolate bar. For a film that's reaching its thirtieth anniversary these effects still stand up remarkably well. Best though is the social conscience. There's the odd nod towards war and ecology, but what about the Oompa-Loompa song  the best of six in the film  where they philosophise over what causes deviant behaviour in children? "You know who's exactly to blame," they conclude, "the mother and the father".As with all works of Dahl, what really makes the film is his wonderful sense of almost malicious perversity. A dark, almost sadistic, air echoes just beneath the surface. Just one question though: has anyone ever got round to reading the sequel, Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator?

Although some of the messages seem a little off. It's a nice movie that captures childlike wonder very well. Maybe a little toxic for todays standards. And the oompa loompas are a little yikes knowing the original. All in all a very lighthearted movie with some poorly ages messages.6/10: but its alright.

reviews.review_title: A great story full of chocolate
reviews.content: When a mysterious character by the name of Willy Wonka decides to open the gates of his secret chocolate factory, five golden tickets are hidden in his chocolate bars for kids to find. Thus, only the lucky finders will have the chance to see the factory and earn a life supply of chocolate. Among other very spoiled children, a very poor and generous boy tries his luck and to his surprise, finds the last golden ticket. Joined by his grandfather, he will discover that Willy and his factory have a lot of temptations prepared for their visitors.It's a wonderful movie about compassion, greed and how kids can become if they don't receive proper education. It's very enjoyable and amusing, while Willy's character is playing a great part in this unique atmosphere. In the end, we'll find Wonka's true intentions regarding his unexpected and special tour, a happy ending being mandatory here. It's a very good movie and a great achievement when taken into consideration the year it was produced and what special effects it includes.

Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory is a decent picture. Acting is a plus, but there are some weakly performed scenes. This is largely due to spotty dialogue and underwhelming character development. Fortunately, Wilder delivers much needed charisma to the story with his convincing persona as the titular character. Still, this wonderful character is criminally underused and undoubtedly underdeveloped, making some scenes more creepy than hilarious, as they could have been. Therefore, the comedy is middling, even with its few great moments. The plot feels very formulaic and rushed, as well, giving way to a resolution that should be satisfying, but fails to be in lack of a setup. Again, this is a result of not introducing the main, or should be main, character until the second act. On top of it, the other lead characters have conflicting motivations throughout, ultimately making them unlikable and leaving the audience extra unsatisfied with the conclusion. Plot holes were abundant, too. The editing was oddly executed, likely failing because of the musicality of the feature that took much away from the plot. The soundtrack itself is split, with a couple good, catchy songs and a few poorly written ones. Scoring turned out to be a plus, though, helping craft a fitting atmosphere for most sequences. Overall, this is a feature with a good premise and awesome lead, that altogether fails to deliver a well written and nicely executed plot.

reviews.review_title: One of my all time favorite children's films
reviews.content: I just rewatched this film today, and it reminded me how much I loved it. Who wouldn't want to visit a chocolate factory?  And for those who don't believe it's a children's film, well, what about The Wizard of Oz?  That film scared me way more than Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.  I admit, it's not a 'sweet' (unless you count the candy - YUM!) film, but most kids aren't that sweet either.  Most children over the age of eight should find it a wild and enjoyable ride.  And I think a lot of kids would be glad to see the brats get their comeuppance.  Remember, these children are exaggerations, so I doubt any kid would see themselves in the character. And last but not least, this is FANTASY.  Not to give anything away, but you know how fairytales end.

I really enjoyed Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory as a kid. I loved the world inside the chocolate factory and very much wanted to visit it one day. I was also really into the stereotyped kids and enjoyed seeing each of the bratty ones get what they deserved. As for Gene Wilder, I think he does a swell job of walking the line between dark and light and really elevates the film. Having recently seen it again I still enjoyed all of the same elements, with the exception of the sets. Wow, the world inside the factory isn't nearly as magical as I remember it. The sets looks downright cheap and amateurish, which weakens the fantasy quotient considerably. Still, this is a film that the kids, and many adults can enjoy.

Wonderful movie, I enjoy watching the movie so much, The Kids acting in the movie was good, except Julie Dawn Cole she was she acting was great, Gene Wilder acting was great, And I can't imagine another actor play Willy Wonka, The songs in the movie was great, The movie was so funny, I recommend watching it and my rating is 9,3/10.

reviews.review_title: Held from perfection by changes from the source material...
reviews.content: I would lie if I told you I didn't enjoy watching this movie. It has wonderful music, acting and a lot of charm! However, I had some criticism and later I compared it to stuff that critics at the time said and I must say I agree with them. There is no overly memorable songs, Gene Wilder completely steals the show (which is good because his performance is fantastic, but bad because Charlie is not in the focus, hence the changed name of the movie compared to the book) and stuff is added/changed for no reason. That doesn't mean this is a bad movie and it is most certainly better than Burton's version in which Wonka acts like a schizophrenic, but it pales when being compared to the masterpiece like "The Wizard of Oz" (some stuff are added/changed here too, but the dynamic of the movie remains stable throughout the whole deal) which is also a musical based on a book for children. All in all, I give the movie 8/10! It's still a wonderful movie, but the fans of the book will notice the difference and will probably be somewhat displeased, while the rest won't even notice, and for them I say 10/10! :)

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie Adaption To The Book!
reviews.content: This movie is the best version of the book, it not only ages well but its such an accurate description to some lines from the book in the movie, its just portrayed in such a great way. No disrespect to Johnny Depp as he is a national treasure and his movie was also very good but I have a strong attachment to this version as its the one I gre up watching, wishing I could go to a chocolate factory just like Charlie bucket.I think this was a remarkable movie and if it was possible a sequel could of been amazing, Gene Wilder was an amazing actor, who accomplished quite a lot in his short time acting.I highly recommend this movie to all fans and non fans, its entertaining enough to absolutely anyone.

Like the great Jack Nicholson lent a bit of his soul to that hack Stephen King in the "Shining," the wondrous Gene Wilder made a relatively stupid book a damn fine film. As a child, I read most of Dahl's fare and found most of it pretty lame (PARTICULARLY his really stupid sequel to "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," what was it called, "The Great Glass Elevator," or something like that?) The only thing he ever wrote that even remotely creeped me out was "The Magic Finger." He should have written that and only that and then gotten a day job. One of the big laughable things about "Willie Wonka" is the Dickensian thing. When not at home Charlie appears to live in the prosperous 1960's USA. But at home, he appears to live the life of Oliver Twist. His ma took in laundry and stirred it in a large cauldron. They hurt for every penny, ate cabbage soup. Where was DFACS? Did they not get food stamps?
And Jack Albertson's character should have been really ashamed of himself. He hadn't been out of bed for twenty years? Once up and about, he seemed quite robust to me. The only thing that makes this movie worth a damn is Gene Wilder. He is a dark master. SPOLIER ALERT!The ending was different also. In the book, Charlie did no wrong. In the movie, he stole Fizzy Lifting Drinks. In the book, Willie Wonka (who had no dark side) suddenly noticed that Charlie was the only one left and declared him the winner. In the movie, he had to pass the final test. (Making the movie superior.)In the movie, the Oompa-Loopmas were orange. In the book they were black. (Making the book racist, but not the movie.) The movie improved upon the book. Roald Dahl was a hack. But at least he had the sense to marry Patricia Neal. As a child, I had a crush on Julie Dawn Cole.

Based on the children's Book Charlie & the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl. Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory is a charming tale of a boy named Charlie who's down on his luck when an opportunely for him and his family opens up when The renowned chocolatier Willy Wonka decides to open up his factory to five children and is introduced to a world of wonder and pure imagination. The movie itself just oozes whimsically fun. From its sets that are very reminiscent of such works as Alice in wonderland and Chitty Chitty Bang Bang. To its iconic songs you get this very colorful fancy family picture., but you get this emotional story through the perspective of charlie seeing this world through his eyes his character we are along for the ride. Charlie himself you feel for him he doesn't have much money and doesn't live in the best living condition with his family. You can see he wants better and more. You feel a connection with this kid. You want him to be rewarded in the end. You spend a fair amount of the beginning of the movie getting to know him and setting up the rest of the kids and just how spoiled and ungrateful they are which perfectly conveys the message of the film. Gene Wilder as Willy is a loving and charming demeanor that is brought to the character from the moment you arrive at the factory. To when he steps out to meet the audience you know that this guy has all kinds of fun tricks up his sleeves. The Wackiness of the factory fitted alongside his personality that's odd, but entertaining at the same time. Everybody else is this bizarre to him it's Tuesday. I also can't help but love the absurda of the film not just from the factory, but even in the beginning with everybody looking for the tickets. You got people bidding on boxes of chocolate and armed escort from airports. That is so ridiculously absurd that it's funny. It's a timeless classic and one that can always be sitting down to down on your own or with the family.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory/1971/****Main Stars: Gene Wilder Jack Albertson Peter OstrumI know I had taken a while to review one of my all-time favorites (which is this film) but I was trying to save this till the last minute. But I decided to review it now since there is nothing else to do. I have finally decided my favorite movie I have seen so far in my lifetime and that would not be this movie but the movie I reviewed before this and that movie is "The Untouchables" and I realize that "The Untouchables" is R rated and is very violent but who cares? I liked it anyway and that's that. Going on this movie is another spectacular film of its time and it is starring Charlie (Peter Ostrum), his grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson), and Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder)! Let me define this movie and I know almost all the lines by heart since I've seen it about a thousand times. Okay, Charlie hears about golden tickets (5) being put into (obviously) 5 Wonka bars being shipped all over the world. Charlie does not have confidence that he is going to win but yet he (You know the story). He discovers an amazing chocolate factory from a chocolate waterfall, to a dark tunnel, to an inventing room, to an Oompa Loompa, to a HSAWAKNOW (which is WONKAWASH spelled backwards), to a Wonkavision room, to another Oompa Loompa, and so on I did not list all of the things Charlie and the other brats saw because I'm too lazy. Going on Charlie (according to Willy Wonka) is the best most docile person inside the factory but Charlie doesn't know that. Then Charlie seems to have more confidence in himself because all the other brats are all gone except for him at the end of the movie. You find out the ending and by now you should know that without me telling you. This film was remade with the same people except Charlie's dad was in the remake. The dad was dead in the original film "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory". The very quirky Tim Burton directed "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. I'm a fan of him but when it came to seeing that movie, I was not too fond of him. Later I went to see "Tim Burton's Corpse Bride" and that was a great movie so I changed my mind again about Tim Burton. Okay?! Got it?! Why did I like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory"? Because I thought the story was very unique (duh Roald Dahl) and because it had good acting esp. by Gene Wilder and it was overall entertaining. Movie directed by Mel Stuart.

A romp that's a quirky 70's picture of childhood innocence, it ends with a position gently anticipating adulthood and responsibility.  Although uneven (the trollish Oompa Loompas are truly demented), Gene Wilder plays the center of a whirlwind of activity, an anchoring performance of a style one wishes more writers would write for him - or anyone.

I finally saw the movie A Fantástica Fábrica de Chocolate (1971) on HBO Max (it recently arrived in Latin America) and I'll tell you what I thought of the movie!I've seen A Fantástica Fábrica de Chocolate remake many times (2005) and for me (because I saw it first) so for me this is better movie than the original (I'm not belittling the movie) it's just my opinion! In this film I saw it so many times that director Tim Burton put it more sentimental and deepened it more and in this 1971 film I didn't see it (I thought I would) and I was wrong!Film viewed on the 30th to the 1st of July 2021.
A magical, inventive, sweet-filled and childhood film. Many generation have watched this. The second one they made I have erased from my memory.

reviews.review_title: Simply sweet and full of pure imagination
reviews.content: I have been a fan of the original Willy Wonka since I was 12 years old, which was way back in 2000-2001. It is my all time favorite movie and the newer remake will never replace it, even if the remake is just OK. The movie is about when the crazy candy maker, Willy Wonka sends out 5 Golden Tickets for a chance to win a tour through his amazing candy factory, run by the mysterious green-haired, orange-faced Oompa Loompa elves, and also win a lifetime supply of chocolate. The children who find them are a spoiled brat named Veruca Salt, a loudmouthed TV addict named Mike Teevee, gumchewer Violet Beauregard, gluttonous Augustus Gloop, and Charlie Bucket--a poor boy who lives with his mom and 4 bedridden grandparents in small house. 4 of the children get their demise thanks to their usual behavior, except for Charlie, and is promised to win a lifetime supply of chocolate, but is almost not given it because he and his Grandpa Joe broke one of Wonka's rules by drinking Fizzy lifting drinks and almost getting chopped to bits by a fan on the ceiling and dirtying it when they bumped into it. However, after Wonka dismisses Charlie and Grandpa Joe, Charlie gives back the Everlasting Gobstopper candy that he gave each of the kids earlier. The gobstopper was Wonka's most secret recipe and he finds out that he passed Mr. Wonka's test of honesty and is given the factory because Mr. Wonka couldn't work there forever, and he wanted to find an honest loving child who can be told all of Wonka's most precious candymaking secrets, and take care of the Oompa Loompas. My favorite parts are when Grandpa Joe does his victory dance "I've Got a Golden Ticket," surprisingly after being bedridden for 20 years, when Charlie finds the ticket and runs home, the psychedelic boat trip, Augustus Gloop falling into the chocolate river, Violet Beauregarde turning into a blueberry thanks to some very special gum, the group first seeing the Chocolate Room, (while Mr. Wonka sings Pure Imagination) when Mr. Wonka leads the group through the beginning of the factory (MR. SALT--Is this some kind of funhouse? WONKA: Why, having fun?) the Wonkawash scene and the very end, when Charlie, Grandpa Joe, and Willy are in the Wonkavator. I know I have more but that's all I can think of. All I can say is, this movie is pure magic, and full of pure imagination, for young and old. So what if it doesn't have fancy computer effects like the 2005 remake? This movie is all real. The 1971 version will always be the best to me, because it's simple, fantastic, magic, funny, and Gene Wilder IS Willy Wonka. Maybe this version isn't true to the book like the 2005 version but this version is special in it's own way. It will remain my favorite movie of all time, with The Muppet Movie probably being second on my list. To end my review, I will say my favorite(and final) line from this movie. "Don't forget what happened to the man who suddenly got everything he always wantedhe lived happily ever after." That line sums up the sheer brilliance and innocence (OK maybe a few parts are a little dark and scary) of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.

I've seen this movie hundreds of times at various ages (ah, the magic of cable), but I never really cared for it. It was well cast, and the kids performed well. But Gene Wilder seemed bored and detached - his brilliance is really only showcased by Mel Brooks. Why were the Oompa Loompas orange? I always hated the musical interludes - they dragged on forever and felt more like filler than story information. The boat ride was just weird, and sent my five year old shaking out of the room. Too many segments didn't follow the book well enough for me. By contrast, I enjoyed Johnny Depp's version, even with the really painfully stereotypical obnoxious children and added back story on Wonka.

reviews.review_title: If you are wise you will listen to me
reviews.content: Quite simply the greatest film ever.  What it may lack in technical expertise (don't forget, it was made in 1971) it makes up for with a wonderful story, superb script and bedazzling performances from all.Ignore any negative comments on here about this film so far.  It is a moral tale showing what happens if you do not pay attention, eat too much, pick up bad habits, are spoilt or watch too much TV (too much tv apparently gives you a pain in the neck and an IQ of 3!).  It champions innocence, honesty and childhood dreams.  As Wonka says "I couldn't leave it to an adult, they would change things".  The factory is a place where anything can (and does) happen.If you've become hardened and desensitised to today's fodder, transport yourself back to your childhood via this film and recapture your glorious youth.Infinitely watchable, wonderful characters - four absolutely beastly children, one underdog; one manic chocolate maker and a host of Oompah Loompahs which were rescued from snozzwangers and vermicious kernids! What more could anyone want.Never forget that "We are the music makers and we are the dreamers of dreams."

reviews.review_title: "Time is a precious thing, never waste it."
reviews.content: Mel Stuart took viewers to a world of pure imagination in his 1971 feature Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. In perhaps his most well-known role, Gene Wilder as the eccentric candy man looking to pass on his chocolate legacy created a brilliant film adaptation of the book, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl. Wilder's exquisite performance proved he could command an entire film, despite him only being in the film's second half. A fun family experience, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory spans generations to bring pure imagination to all ages.Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder), candy extraordinaire is well known for being a recluse in his chocolate factory. Fearing intrusion, he has locked himself in his factory free to invent and produce the best chocolate the world has known without threat. When word breaks that Willy Wonka will open his factory to 5 winners of golden tickets hidden in his chocolate bars, the world is stunned as they all scatter, ravishing his bars to gain entry into his elusive chocolate paradise. Young Charlie Bucket (Peter Ostrum) of meager means, believes that he has to win a golden ticket because he wants the prize more than anyone else does. After all 5 of the golden tickets are discovered, Charlie cries in his room devastated to have missed out on meeting the man his grandfather always told him stories about. To console himself, Charlie treats himself to a Wonka bar after he finds some money in the street. To his surprise, just after he buys the bar, the news breaks that the fifth golden ticket was a fake. With the last shred of hope in him, Charlie opens his bar to find a glimmer of gold around his candy bar. After racing home to tell his family the good news, Charlie, and Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson) prepare for their trip to the chocolate factory the next day. Wearing a purple velvet coat, Willy Wonka greets the guests to his factory walking with a cane, that he gets stuck in a brick and falls forward in a fantastic somersault. From this point on, Willy Wonka's credibility is questioned as he leads the children and their families through his factory where there are "little surprises around every turn". Some of those surprises result in removal of the children from the factory until only Charlie is left to discover Willy Wonka's motives for opening his chocolate paradise. Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a sincere treat for children and parents alike. A fun moral movie that is never too overt with its message, Willy Wonka is an experience to have as often as possible. The worst part of this movie is waiting the 47 minutes of well-done build-up before we actually get to see Willy Wonka. Gene Wilder is fantastic in the role of the mysterious peculiar owner of the candy empire. He has his perfect moments of emotion, which he is often accused of overdoing the yelling--a criticism I find unfounded. I read that he had to fight to have his opening scene filmed the way that made it into the movie, with his walking being aided by a cane. It was a good decision on behalf of Mel Stuart to relent and film it this way, because, from that moment on, you never knew what Mr. Wonka was capable of, nor did you understand his motives. This mystery was necessary to the story, and a bit of the premise the film depends on upon would have been lost without it. This bit of trivia just further goes to support what an acting genius Gene Wilder is.Always do as your told, follow rules and authority, adults are looking out for your best interests are the easy messages to take away from this film. Upon closer inspection, however, one can see that the adults are no better equipped to look after themselves than their children are. It is an adult that is trying to steal from Mr. Wonka, and get the kids to steal his secrets, it is the adults that are encouraging their kids to do Slugworth's bidding, and it is the adults who find it difficult to resist the temptations around them. Maybe the bigger message is that there's a little childlike wonder left in all of us, as long as we don't try to hard to extinguish it. The adults become just as enchanted as the children when they first enter Mr. Wonka's brilliant candy-filled world. Maybe, just maybe, the underlying message is that we all advance in age as we make it through life, but if we are careful, we never have to grow up. I stick with that message, Willy Wonka doesn't live too bad of a life, after all.

reviews.review_title: As a movie, good. As a musical, bad.
reviews.content: I loved the book. Gene Wilder did an exceptional job as Wonka.But why a musical? It wasn't necessary. It wasn't what the book was about. Yeah, the Oompa-Loompa's "sang" in the book, but the words were completely different. And there was a Mr. Bucket, Charlie's father, in the book. But he wasn't in the movie at all. What's up with that? I haven't seen the remake yet. I'm sure it's just as good, if not better, than this film. But I know it's not a musical like the original. (At least I hope it isn't.)My only other problem is how it ended. Mr. Wonka, Charlie, and Grandpa Joe were in the Great Glass Elevator; (although Mr. Wonka calls it a "Wonkavator") the last part was them flying through the sky.In the book, they actually go back to Charlie's house and pick up the rest of the family. They don't do it in this movie. Why? Other than that, it's not bad. I just wish they hadn't turned it into a musical.My REAL score: 6/10

reviews.review_title: Frustrating. This movie could have been and should have been so much better.
reviews.content: Well the first thing you should notice about this film is that the life of Charlie Bucket seems to be nothing more than a cruel, endless cycle of crushing poverty and cabbage water. That is until...I've seen this film a number of times over the years and sadly with all it's great potential it never does completely deliver. Which is a shame, because the film has a terrifically quirky and unusual premise. But I refuse to lie to myself, because I can readily see and hear the many flaws in this film, especially in it's first half, which alternates from being drab and boring, to shrill and irritating. All the while very little of it's humor gels together, making for some very tedious viewing, worse yet are those lame, go-nowhere songs that occur early in the movie. It's only when they get to the Wonka factory that things pick up and the films eccentricities immediately increase ten-fold. However half of this movie IS boring. Gene Wilder (RIP) is simply fantastic as Willy Wonka, the eccentric King of Candy and his performance is, unquestionably, the best thing about the movie; he injects the film with some desperately needed energy, excitement and purpose - which partly makes up for the films painfully slow start.Not surprisingly the second half of the movie is much better, as we the audience are treated to a walking tour of Mr. Wonka's one-of-a-kind chocolate factory, where there is a surprise around every corner. With that being said I think Warner Brothers could have definitely splashed more cash on this film, as I find Wonka's factory, on a visual basis, to be small in scale and a bit underwhelming in it's design; starting with the factory's front gate, in fact from an exterior standpoint, there isn't a single thing that catches your eye, it's completely plain Jane on the outside. The interior sets fare better, but still this film will never win any Oscar's for Art Direction or Set Design, yet had this film been made to the caliber that it should have been, it would have easily won in both those categories. But sadly I find Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory to be a rather ponderous and distinctly underwhelming experience and 46 years after it's release the whole film looks very, very dated. It looks ugly. And while on that note, of all the movies I've ever seen, this film must have one of the ugliest casts of all time; who are made even uglier by their bad clothes and worse hair-cuts and/or comb-overs - particularly the parents of the contest winners. And surely I'm not alone with my hatred for that loud-mouthed, spoiled-rotten, bratty little bitch, Veruca "I WANT IT NOW!" Salt! SHE SUCKS! As does her repulsively irritating pappy; these two characters are more a detriment to the film then they are an asset, curiously enough I do like her song though, which is the only one of the movies numerous songs that catches my ear. On her singing number you could say that her bitchiness finally paid off in her final scene, right before Wonka's "Eggdicator" determines her, correctly, to be a bad egg.Throughout the tour Willy Wonka keeps things going in a very lively and quirky direction, his factory is indeed loaded with many gimmicks and surprises. Including the fact that in every other room of his factory it looks like there are numerous health code violations being committed, as things often look unsanitary. And is anyone going to object when I mention the fact that machine/set that makes Wonka's "Everlasting Gobstopper's" looks as lame, as it does cheap. They clearly didn't try too hard on that one. Once again the Wonka factory should have been a supreme showpiece, a marvel of set design, but unfortunately that's not what we get and that's another missed opportunity, in fact you can say that about nearly every aspect of this film. I have this theory that had it been made 15 years later, in the mid-80's, it would have been so much better, that would have been the perfect time for this movie (for multiple reasons) - not 1971. For instance when this was made Gene Wilder was only in his late-30's, yet at the end of the movie he's all ready to give his factory away to Charlie. What sense does that make??? Early retirement? Then there's the aforementioned dated appearance of the film. The way I see it it's a shame that this project wasn't shelved for a decade-and-a-half. With all that being said Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is still a much better than Tim Burton and Johnny Depp's hideous remake "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", which has the same problems as the first film, only in reverse; the factory looks spectacular, however, the film is utterly ruined by Johnny Depp's hideous performance. Depp made for a VERY weak and effeminate Willy Wonka, a real dandy - Wilder was infinitely better in the role.Ultimately for the reasons given I find Willy Wonka and the Chocholate Factory to be a frustrating and disappointing movie, which had the potential to be a lot better than it ultimately is. This film stands as one of the best examples of Hollywood failing to seize upon and capitalize on what should have been a golden screen epic. Instead it's a botched and somewhat lazily executed film.... but still much better then Burton's Blunder.On a lighter note, whose with me on thinking that "the most perfect high in existence" could be achieved through the lighter-than-air combination of Willy Wonka's Fizzy Lifting Drink and (if I were a druggie) a giant, slow-burning, reefer one that's over-flowing with the worlds most potent pot. Tell me that wouldn't be quite a marvelous combination... made better yet if Wonka himself were to make clouds of cotton-candy, as they float low and lazily, that would only further the experience as you're on your way up-up-up to ethereal ecstasy.

reviews.review_title: When you watch this film creation, you will find yourself in a world of pure imagination!
reviews.content: "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" (1971), I remember the very first time I saw this movie as a child. To this day, I'm still blown away with how great this film is. It has found a spot on my list of my top 10 all-time favorite family films. It has a perfect story, perfect acting, perfect sets/locations, perfect special effects, and of course a perfect soundtrack to tie it together. The storyline is based off the book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", written by Roald Dahl. Originally, the film script was going to be written entirely by Roald Dahl himself, along with David Seltzer. However, since Roald Dahl failed to meet deadlines, David Seltzer did some rewrites to the script and the story was changed. Now, in most cases, changing an original story from a book for cinema standards can make or break it. However, in the case of this movie, the changes made the plot line in the movie are a good thing. It made the film that much more entertaining than the original novel. Don't get me wrong, I still love the original book. It's a lot of fun to read! Here's something that might shock you, Roald Dahl hated this movie adaptation of his book so much that he disowned it! I can understand his anger of his book being changed. If you were in his shoes, you would probably feel upset too! But, for our benefit, the movie came out fantastic and the storyline keeps you hooked from beginning to end. Sorry, Roald Dahl..... I really love this film! As for the acting, it is stellar from all of the actors and actresses. The top three standout performances come from the one and only Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka, Peter Ostrum as Charlie Bucket and Jack Albertson as Grandpa Joe. They really make this movie! Gene Wilder is legendary and iconic as Willy Wonka. Peter Ostrum is absolutely phenomenal and charming as Charlie Bucket and Jack Albertson is funny and heartwarming as Grandpa Joe. Here's an interesting bit of history for you. This was the only role that Peter Ostrum played in his acting career. Isn't that something? This was the only time that Peter Ostrum acted in a motion picture. But, what a great performance it was! It's a shame that he didn't pursue acting any further, he had great potential. He is currently a veterinarian, which is still cool. It's what he wants to be, and who are we to deny him? As for the rest of the actors and actresses in this movie, they fire on all cylinders as well and definitely help bring this film to life! All of the sets/locations are perfect and give this film an amazing atmosphere. Of course, my favorite set in this movie has to be the Chocolate Room. Whenever I see a screenshot, or film clip of that room I can immediately pinpoint it to this movie. Talk about an iconic set! All of the rest of the rooms in the factory are just as breathtaking. As for the special effects, they are all very well-done. Some of them can get a bit cheesy at times, but that's what helps to give this movie it's special charm! Finally, the soundtrack written by: Leslie Bricusse, Anthony Newley and Walter Scharf is amazing and helps to tie the whole film together. I could hear any random part of this film score, and know right away that it's from this movie. That's the mark of a phenomenal film score! "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" is nothing but cinematic gold for people of all ages. I can watch it over and over again and never get tired of it. Of course, I give this movie 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you haven't seen this film, go watch it, especially if you have kids. You'll make them very happy! I guarantee that they'll love this movie, and you will too. Grab your golden ticket, and prepare for an adventure!

reviews.review_title: It's probably been said before, but this movie is a classic.
reviews.content: Okay, it may not be faithful to the book (then again, has there ever been a novel based movie faithful to the books?), but it's still a lovable film with charm and character.The special effects in this film are rather realistic looking. That's kind of ironic, because this is one of these films where the special effects are more realistic than the ones in the remake. And the remake was made in 2005! What does that tell you? The plot is rather good too. Sure, like I said, it strays from the book in some ways, but the characters seem to be more faithful to the book. Charlie is a normal human boy with flaws like everyone else. Violet isn't a tomboy and has a feminazi mother, Veruca throws tantrums and screams and the TV addict boy is smart as well as smart allecky. And Willy Wonka seemed more likable in this version as well.My favorite parts are the Oompa Loompa songs and the creepy boat ride scene. Come on, who wasn't freaked out by the boat scene when they were little? Sad that they don't make movies like this anymore. I recommend this movie all the way!

I dare you to try convincing me that Wonka wasn't planning their deaths (and yes they are all dead) all along.Even though it is really fun to examine the darker undertone of this film (workplace violations, children dying left and right, Wonka being suicidal and impotent), it is equally fun just watching the film, because it does perhaps the best thing a film like this can do for an adult, make them feel like a child again.What I mean by this is that the entire film just gives off such a child-like sense of wonder, but not in a bad way, or even a way that feels cringey. The sets, the songs, the acting, it all comes together in such a delightful way even though Grandpa Joe is letting his family starve because he's too lazy to get out of bed.And every single character is so memorable, and every single one has at least one hilarious moment, like Charlie's teacher. He might only be in two scenes, but damn it he does not get enough credit. Gene Wilder definitely gets enough credit, but I'll give him a little more because he's funny, he's crazy, he's a little bit creepy, and he's everything Willy Wonka should be. And even the kids didn't set my teeth on edge unless they were supposed to.I did think the first half lacked a certain energy that a musical like this should have, and there are some bizarre tonal shifts in this portion too, but watching this film is like having a big gulp of a fizzy lifting drink, it fills you up and makes you feel warm and cosy, without the imminent threat of death at the merciless rotors of a giant fan. And I could never complain about that.

With the colourful directing of Mel Stuart, the fun, singable, songs of Bricusse and Newley, and the rags-to-golden ticket odyssey of poor, lovable Charlie Bucket, "Willy Wonka..." succeeds in being enjoyed by many.I, honestly, never tire of watching it, finding each time I watch it, something new and funny that I might have missed over the 25 years I have seen it.Brilliant family fare!!

reviews.content: I was five when I first saw Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, as I'm sure everyone else was. And now, at a ripe old age, I still think it's an enjoyable farce. But, rather like The Wizard of Oz, the beauty of this film doesn't lie in the script or the acting, but rather in the glorious set designs. Yes, it's quite obvious that much of the `candy' is a bunch of inflatable balloons, but they are a real treat for the eyes. Looking at all the chocolate is also very pleasant. (Mmm chocolate). But, then again if you've turned into a cynical snob, don't bother with this. But I think that Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory is very impressive. It's not groundbreaking, but it's whimsy and enjoyable. And that's good enough. 7.2 out of 10.

I first saw this on VHS tape in the early-90s at a friend's house. I found the film creepy and outdated. Watching it as an adult was a refreshing experience and here's the takeaways:* Gene Wilder plays every scene with a delicious naughtiness. Quoting classic literature and delivering every line with perfect comic timing and deadpan delivery. Can you imagine Roald Dahl's preferred choice of Spike Milligan playing Willy Wonka?* The film has a lot of dark comedy. I was a huge fan of Roald Dahl when I was a child and there was often a dark streak to his children's novels.* There is some great photography in places.* Every song is great in my opinion. Most musicals rarely have more than two good songs.The bad bits:
* Some of the set design is very cheap looking. The giant sweets that look like painted beach balls, the fibreglass mushrooms, the chocolate river that looks more like mud.* With it being a 70s film, the boat scene is bit psychedelic, man. Very much of its time.* Unfortunately, it inspired Tim Burton to create an insipid and camp, but not very sincere remake.Overall, it is a bit creepy, I can't deny it. It's also possibly a bit too scary for very young children. All that said it is a fun romp and has left a cultural legacy which clearly visible by the number of songs that sample audio from the film.

Quite the cult film these days, "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" deserves its plaudits, as a well-judged translation of Roald Dahl to film. Dahl's books for children are phenomenally successful in this country; a kind of dry, larger-than-life misanthropy comes through in most of books, along with some moralizing, that tends to exclusively take the child's side. He is a very skilled writer, and adapts his book with pretty much all of the black humour and colourful anarchy intact.Yes, some musical sequences are a trifle stilted; "Cheer Up Charlie" just doesn't work in any satisfactory way. In very much a 60s-early 70s musical way, Bricusse and Newley's "Candy Man" and "Imagination" work, but are not especially brilliant, or enhancing. The Oompa Lumpas' songs and Veruca Salt's precocious, petulant number are pretty good, mind, and really develop the film's moral basis.Set design is truly the strength of the film, appealingly and at times surreally visualizing the Chocolate Factory. Of course, Gene Wilder is the other coup d'etat of the production; coming over as a maniacal, wondrous and deadpan presence. Much of the appeal this film holds for older viewers has to go down to Wilder's wonderfully pitched Wonka: he really defines the part and defies one to think of anyone else in it. Julie Dawn Cole is the most impressive of the juvenile actors; coming over as the ultimate petulant, nigh-on demonic brat of a child. Her comeuppance is lovingly signposted in her musical sequence and then the dispatching. Each child who fails the test is amusingly and quite disturbingly dispatched by a diffident, sardonic Wonka, and then we are given quite sublime little epigrammatic songs by the Oompa Lumpas stating the moral. Some heady stuff for a children's film - "Who's to blame?"/"It's the MOTHER AND THE FATHER!"
Some eccentric aspects of the book become a little odd on film, like the whole family set-up of the Buckets. Grandpa Joe, as enacted in the flesh, comes across as an increasingly questionable figure - his past laziness seems incorrigibly absurd, and he's seen to touch up some other female attendant of one of the children, when they are in a lift - "What are you doing?!" she says. Very curious stuff! Charlie is a simpering bland child who I suppose will do; really it's what you'd expect in a story which has to portray a quite simple idea of virtue and goodness. His being a blue-eyed Aryan child and Grandpa Joe and the rest of the lethargic family being quite obvious American Jews is slightly singular. The setting of the film is another thing; where is Wonka's factory and where does this American Bucket family live? The direction, by Mel Stuart, is maybe at times pedestrian... this is an area where maybe things could have been furthered, but it's an inoffensive, acceptable direction of the film really.As sure as Alastair Cooke being on the BBC, I liked this film. I can find few flaws as to its achieving what it sets out to do. The original book and concept maybe has its flaws to an older viewer, but it's damn well delicious stuff for any child, and there are too few films of which you can say that. The set designers and Gene Wilder really deserve bounteous praise for great efforts which lift the whole thing to its quality.Rating:- ****/*****

Based on the Roald Dahl novel 'Charlie And The Chocolate Factory', 'WWATCF' is about 5 lucky kids who win the opportunity to tour the infamous Willy Wonka's chocolate factory.The 5 chosen are: Augustus Gloop, a German boy who eats too much; Veruca Salt, a spoilt rich brat; Violet Beauregarde, gum-chewer extroadinaire; Mike Teavee, TV lover and Charlie Bucket, the main character of the film.Part-comedy, part-musical, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a delightful family film with amazing sets, a funny script and hilarious songs.So next time it's on TV, don't by-pass it. Join in the fun... it's, erm, sweet!

I have loved this film since childhood, and like all good films that children like, it has stood up to the well-earned cynicism of my adulthood. That is of course because it is good on binary levels; that of a beloved kid's movie and a sentimental disportment for adults.  That is why it is not only endearing, but enduring.An entertaining mix of irony, camp and charm, it is made of the stuff that produces dreams in the young and a longing for insouciance for the old.  Who could resist this fantasy world within the walls of that enigmatic candy factory where the wallpaper is edible and rivers flow with chocolate?   Who could not hum along with the crafty music numbers (mega kudos to songwriters Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley)?  And of course who could not love the homunculin Oompa Loompas?   The child actors/actresses are great.  They serve to provide a certain satisfaction to the audience because in truth there is a reticent schadenfreude in seeing bratty kids get a comeuppance or two.   And not enough can be said about Gene Wilder.  He is brilliant in this role that has a underlying Oscar Wilde wit to it.  In fact his appearance is a demarcated turning point in the movie in both tone and irony.  I'm not sure who else could have pulled off this unique mix of lovability and acidulousness.

reviews.review_title: A Film of Chocolaty joy for the whole family
reviews.content: This is an amazing film, much better than the 2005 remake. It is nice to see the early 70's sets which seemed much more extravagant as a kid, but you have to appreciate them. The cast is much better than the remake. Gene Wilder's Willy Wonka is more of a favourable character than Johnny Depp's and Granpa Joe will keep a smile on your face. The special effects were top of the range back in the 70's and they have had influence on a number of other films (especially the shrinking of Mike Teevee. Everyone's favourite character of the film is Wonka himself, who is a quirky character but seems to be hiding something. Charlie has to be the second (if not joint first) favourite character with his innocence and correct morals (even if some people don't like that he decided to buy chocolate instead of giving it to his family (but those people are just being pedantic), besides he does give some of the money to them). Then there is Grandpa Joe, who is enlightened and re-energised by Charlie. There are also four other children who everyone loves to see get what they deserve. And then there is the small, but wonderful Oompa-Loompas that give the feel of Oompa-Land. All I can say to sum up is that the film is full of great music, it is enjoyable for all the family and it is a film of Pure Imagination.

reviews.review_title: 40 years later, still a delightful classic
reviews.content: I rewatched this movie a few nights ago for the first time in almost 10 years, and I'm surprised of just how well it holds up. Sure it's dated and it's not as impressive now as it was back then, but I love how this is entire film is practical and we're able to pull of some very nice set design and interesting looking props and sequences.The thing that holds up the most is the writing and characters. Though the movie doesn't follow the book exactly to a tee, I kind of like it better that way. An adaptation doesn't need to be an 100% carbon copy of the source material to be accepted as good. The Lord of the Rings movies had some minor changes to the story every now and then, but most fans didn't mind or actually applauded the changes. Funnily enough, the 2005 Tim Burton adaptation tried to be closer to the Ronald Dahl book and was rated slightly lower for it, though it's not a bad film.I like how they made Charlie a good hearted but still fallible young boy who still has a weakness of being tempted and even possibly falling into greed (though he never fully does) compared to Freddie Higmore's character in the Burton film who acts like a little messiah who can do no wrong, which always felt off.Of cours I have to talk about the star of the show, Willy Wonka himself. Gene Wilder was the perfect choice for the character and basically steals the movie for all the time he has on screen. He has the wonder of a child, but the wisdom, wit and professionalism of an adult. I love how all the parents in the film think he's a crooked and terrible man who doesn't care about what happens to the children, but he obviously does and knows that none of them will come to any real harm. He's amazing and often very funny.One thing I never truly understood as kid was the films ending, but now that I saw it recently, I think I finally do. I will be spoiling the end of this film so if you haven't seen it, I advise you stop reading and go watch it yourself.Wonka's final test to Charlie always seemed very jarring to me and can be taken as cruel, the way he shout at both Grandpa Joe and him is pretty callous, since they never actually stole the fizzy lifting drinks. It was simply a test of overcoming the temptation of greed where Charlie has to be courageous enough to give the gobstopper back to Wonka that he would have given to "Slugworth" for the cash prize, and since Charlie is poor along with his family, this would be extremely tempting for him. Though Charlie doesn't do this, he resists the temptation in exchange for a good deed to Wonka that he now trusts.A lot of people probably have imagined what would have happened if Charlie gave the gobstopper to "Slugworth" himself. I'm pretty sure what would've happened is that Charlie and his family would have gotten a cash prize that would have benifited them. He wouldn't have walked away with nothing, but he would've never known about the possibility of winning the factory itself.Anyway that's my opinion of this great film and my understanding of the message behind it and the entire test that the factory tour was based around. Except for the scary tunnel scene, I still have no idea what the hell that's supposed to mean.

I LOVE this movie. I love it more now, than when I was a kid.The best thing about this movie is that it not only pioneered but nailed - and I mean, absolutely NAILED - the concept of appealing to kids on one level, adults on a completely different level. This is one of the hardest things to do in movies, but if done well is an absolute delight. Kids can watch this movie and be enthralled by the Oompa-Loompas and the spectacle and the effects. Adults can be tickled by the smart, snappy dialogue and by Gene Wilder being a sarcastic wiseacre throughout, in what must be considered the role of his career.All the parts were nailed. You can't imagine anyone else in the roles as they were cast. You hated Veruca because she was just so spoiled. You winced at Mike TeeVee's, Augustus's and Violet's fatal flaws. Especially juxtaposed against this motley crew, you appreciated Charlie Bucket and his Grandpa Joe for their earnestness and unpretentiousness all the more. Truly they were the moral center of the piece.Other movies and shows have done a good job of appealing to both kids and adults on different levels, but this is the gold standard to which all must ultimately answer to.See it. And if you've seen it already, see it again.10/10.
