Good retelling of Roald Dahl's story, tightening some loose screws.  The idea of making it a musical was good, considering the songs.  Two classics ("Candy Man", "Pure Imagination");  two good songs ("I Want it Now" and "I've Got a Golden Ticket").  Unfortunately, what it needs is an "11 o'clocker" -- a song closer to the finale that lifts the mood.  A little patter song by Willy Wonka, perhaps, about the loss of the children.  In the second act, after "Pure Imagination", "I Want it Now" is all we have except the wearisome Oompa-Loompa song.Gene Wilder is a marvel.  It was dangerous using an actor not so well known and not bringing him in for forty minutes of building him up.  He doesn't disappoint at all.  He captures Willy so perfectly one is surprised, re-reading to book, to find Wonka is short.The children are actually quite good, too, especially the ones playing Charlie and Veruca.

reviews.review_title: My review for my Film Analysis and Exploration class
reviews.content: Calling a movie your all time favorite is quite a task. I believe I was around seven years old when I first watched Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Ever since that first viewing, I have been in love with the film and its incredible diegesis. Though the film all together is a wonderful timeless piece, for the purpose of my review I want to start when the winners of the golden tickets enter the factory with their parents. As they travel along the many rooms, corridors, tunnels, and halls of the factory, the viewer learns more about each individual child and, more importantly, what is characteristically wrong with them and their parents. Though Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory captures the viewer through Gene Wilder's quirky character and the sensory delightfulness of the factory, one of the most important things the viewer takes away from this film are morals. More specifically, to be polite, selfless, kind, respectful everything that our parents are suppose to teach us and are deemed desirable by society. What makes this message so universal is the fact that not only is it meant for children but adults as well. The viewer learns these "lessons" from all of the children as well as their parents, who are partly if not entirely to blame for their behavior. The first child to be taken away is Augustus Gloop, a fat little boy who falls into the chocolate river. Even though Willy Wonka tells Augustus to stay away from the river, the boy is disobedient and even falls in and gets sucked up into a pipe. His fault is gluttony. Three other children all share similar fates, all representing an imperfection in society. The second child, Veruca Salt, is terribly spoiled by her father and demands to have one of the golden egg laying geese inside the factory. She attempts to get one and is deemed a "bad egg" and sent down a chute, followed by her father. She is, of course, greed. The two other children personify stubbornness and rudeness and are both punished for it; one by becoming a human blueberry, the other, turned into a micro-sized version of himself. The protagonist of the film, Charlie, is the only child left at the end of the factory tour. However, since he is only human, him and his grandfather (the only respectable parental figure besides, perhaps, Wonka himself) drink a fizzy soda that makes the both of them float up to the ceiling. Unlike the other participants, their predicament is only temporary. Even so, Willy Wonka is displeased with them and tells them to leave. Being obedient, regretful, and respectful, they exit the factory. Only through their act of humility does Wonka present them with the ultimate prize, the factory itself. This sends an obvious message to the viewer of what attributes are right and which ones are wrong.It was only recently that I realized Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory was made in 1971. I knew it was an old movie, but I was shocked to find out it is over forty years old. Once the characters enter the factory, time seems to stop. There is nothing dated in the factory, save for the television, and the characters themselves don't necessarily give away a time period. These elements, along with the very universal message the film is sending, make it sincerely timeless. People in twenty years from today can watch this movie and still take away from it, young and old.

reviews.review_title: I don't know why it's rated so highly, but it's probably because of the similarities to "Singin' in the Rain." It's a funny, heart-warming musical.
reviews.content: "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" was based on Road Dahl's book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". It's about a young boy named Charlie who gets a Golden Ticket. This ticket allows him and a parent to enter the Chocolate Factory owned by Willy Wonka. There, we get something similar to a horror film-children are picked of one by one. Why? Because they are bad children.I enjoyed this film, but I can't see why so many people like it. I thought the music was fantastic (ecspecially the "I got a Golden Ticket" song.) I thought it also had some good jokes, but I forgot what they were.My only guess is that this-and the fact that it may be heart-warming to some is why people like it. For me, it was too weird and kind of overdid it. "Being John Malcovich" had a style of inventiveness, but this just seemed like many other films being called original; It's an adventure film with weird things that often appear.I enjoyed it, but I never found it heart-warming.Fans of this will like "Singin' in the Rain" (1952) and possibly "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory." (2005) Feel free to send me a Private Message regarding this comment.

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie Gene Wilder ever did
reviews.content: This movie that Gene did made me realize how much I love acting. During my senior year in high school, I got to play Willie Wonka in a play that the theatre put on. It turned out to be a big success. Everyone love it. I thank you very much Gene Wilder. Your acting inspired me to try something that I never thought I could do. I also want to mention that the songs were the best for the movie. To anyone who is reading this summary of mine, THIS MOVIE IS A MUST SEE. It is the best movie I have ever seen and still today I watch it alot.

Viewing Willy Wonka and the Chocolate factory as a child and as a young adult I appreciated it's whimsical appearance and it's fantastic story. Not until recently did I discover the religious symbolism that runs throughout the film. I've never read the book which the film was based upon so I can't say if there are any similarities regarding religious symbolism in the book. The Religious spin: Wonka represents God The Chocolate factory represents Heaven or Eden Slugworth represents the Devil The everlasting gobstopper represents the soul The story essentially tells the tale of how mankind is offered the opportunity (the golden ticket) to reap Heaven (Chocolate factory). The opportunities are few in a world littered with corruption. The adults of the world are portrayed as cynical, untrusting or untrustworthy. The golden tickets find their way into the hands of children. Charlie, the protagonist of the story, is shown to be the kindest and most humble. Upon receiving their tickets the children are immediately confronted by Slugworth (the Devil) who whispers temptation into their ears. The first impression we are provided of the reclusive Wonka (God) is that of a prankster, as he shyly limps out only to tumble forward evoking both shock and delight. Throughout the film the Wonka character expresses a gamut of emotions to the point of knowing what he is like but not understanding him. He's both structured and chaotic. Upon entering the factory the guests are provided rules (some visible while others are practically invisible). The guests are instructed to sign that they will obey the rules (Symbolic of Adam and Eve). During the story each of the children fall prey to a number of the deadly sins; Augustus (gluttony), Veruca (greed), Violet (envy/vanity), Charlie (envy), and Mike (vanity). In each case the sin brings shame and disastrous results. One of the most famous quotable lines from the film is the Wonka statement,'We are the music makers. We are the dreamers of dreams'. Wonka (God) is stating 1. The relationship between He (God) and his guests (humans) exists when expressing We and that they each share the ability to create. And, 2. that the infinite is possible. With Wonka (God) all things are possible.Throughout the story appear the Oompa Loompas (Angels) who do the bidding of Wonka and provide sage advice for those who've fallen prey to sin. At one point in the story the children are each offered Wonka's greatest invention, the Everlasting Gobstopper. He informs them that this special treat will last forever and instructs them that it can never land in the hands of Slugworth (Devil). The children and their parents eye one another expressing their understanding of it's significance and of Slugworth's desire for it. In the end only Charlie and his Uncle remain at the conclusion of the tour. Wonka shows them the door and turns away to go about his business. Confused, they inquire about the chocolate and they're rebuffed by Wonka who scolds them for disobeying the rules. At this point Wonka (God) appears cold and distant. Charlie's Uncle, experienced to the corruption of the world (and victim of his own slothfulness), suggests to Charlie that they deal with Slugworth. Unswayed, Charlie, expressing remorse for his actions, offers the Everlasting Gobstopper (Soul) back to Wonka. Wonka turns to Charlie with a look of gratefulness and forgiveness. He tells Charlie that he did it. He passed the test. He returned the Gobstopper without letting it fall into the hands of Slugworth. Moments later, Slugworth enters the room. At first Charlie and his Uncle are taken aback by his presence, but, they are informed that Slugworth actually works for Wonka. The ominous presence previously embodied by Slugworth dissolves as he provides them with a congratulatory smile. In the final climax Charlie, having received the Chocolate Factory, takes a ride with Wonka up into the heavens. Much can be derived from the symbolic nature of the film and what it potentially is suggesting. Most notably the idea that the Devil actually works for God for the purpose of providing man with temptation in order to test his/her trustworthiness. To some that conclusion might appear to place man at a disadvantage. But, certainly not more so than what original man (Adam and Eve) had to face. Mankind still has free will. The Slugworth character (Devil) can be perceived much the same as a tool, albeit a dangerous one. A tool that enables men to act out poor choices. Similar to the adage that guns don't kill people, people kill people. The tool in the wrong hands can be a dangerous weapon but if it's ignored it's harmless. What I found most satisfactory about the potential symbolic nature of the film was that beneath it's whimsical appearance and fantastic story lie a moralistic teaching. It is a story meant to be seen by children and beyond entertaining them provide them lessons (some visible and some practically invisible) on how they should conduct themselves. And, potentially save themselves. I don't suspect that the soon to be released remake, directed by Tim Burton, will provide such lessons. The last and most intriguing question that I have regarding the Religious spin of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate factory is by who's design does it occur. Was it the author of the book? The screenwriter? The director? Or, by some other providence??

This movie is one of the most fun movies of all time!  I absolutely loved this movie as a child, and my children and grandchildren will love it in the future!  Who wouldn't want to be in a world of 'pure imagination' and candy? Gene Wilder delivers an unforgettable performance as Willy Wonka! 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Film plays like a "Goosebumps" tale...But fun
reviews.content: I remember watching this in 5th grade.  I thought it was a fun show.  But, last night, I saw it again on TV for the first time in 5 years.  Now that I'm older, I see that the "children's" movie has some devilish hints to it.  Such quotes as "Candy is Dandy, but Liquor is Quicker" and "Well, the furnace only lights every other day, so they might survive"made me wonder if Willy Wonka *really* liked kids.  Personally, I didn't like the Oompa Loompas either.  THEIR basic message is that if children don't behave, they should be disposed of.  Now, isn't that a bit mean-spirited for this kind of movie?  What's going on here?  Makes you wonder just what happened to all those children taken away by the Oompa Loompas.  Maybe that's just Gene Wilder humor, but if it is, then he shouldn't have been cast for this innocent, child-loving role.  No matter.  Despite all this, it's a fun movie and I liked the Grandpa.

reviews.review_title: Simply a wonderfully made film for it's time
reviews.content: I may now be a little spoiled by the Tim Burton remake, but I not only saw this one before it, I grew up watching it (plus Wonka is better in this one). This classic film features a good music track and a heart-felt, engaging, and loving story like no other. A boy from a poor family wins the big prize touring probably one of the most interesting and exciting fictional factories man would have ever known. With some amazing feats for it's time, fun scenery, and a colorful cast of characters (especially Wonka himself), this old classic shall remain one of the most fun and sweet ideas in film history.

reviews.review_title: If you want to view paradise...
reviews.content: This was my favourite movie when I was 8 and I still curl up and watch it every so often with my 6 year old nephew. Full of pure imagination and wonderful characters that could only be created by author Raoul Dahl! Good music and a downright zany plot, kids and parents should both enjoy this movie. Gene Wilder is simply delightful as Willy Wonka.

reviews.review_title: Important moral and a film of movie making history. - Amazing to see where other movies quote this original screenplay.
reviews.content: I really enjoyed this gem (and had to see which history Burton had to fuzz with with his 2005 adaptation!). For a 70s children-grownup fairytale morality flick, this was pretty amusing: I was as curious as the kids when we as the audience entered with them the factory! Paradise awaits!I really enjoyed the simplicity (not too many different sets, well chosen on-location settings (Munich has some great places!) and - from today's view' -seemingly 'low budget' ideas... that pretty much convey the message.I felt right in 'Alice in Wonderland' and believe many other artists adapted pieces of the set (and sweets design)... how about the Weasley Brothers from Harry Potter? And (earlier and recent) costumes of DC's Joker had some significant similarities, wether by accident or not.I really do enjoy the way it skillfully blends entertainment and a serious underlying moral, even if Roald Dahl did not love the movie adaptation of his (very genius!) story... This movie is for kids and grown-ups and conveys still the same things to both of them. Don't get greedy or all the other things and good things will be handed to you! (and other things)It is really a must see, a fairy tale made in the 70s with other technology than today - simple tools, massive outcome. This is how good movies are made: with loads of imagination and a good story.

I'm gonna be 100% honest. I usually only a give 10/10 rating when a movie is close to being perfect, when it does everything right. This is not the case with Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, a movie that is flawed, indeed. But the movie is incredibly original, it has a magical feel that I'm not sure many other movies have and has become a part of film and culture in general, that the movie deserves a 10/10 rating.Let's talk about the flaws of the movie first. I understand the film is based on a children's book, but the characters in the film, particularly the parents of the children feel incredibly clichéd and extreme in their way of being. Veruca's father, for example: he's a rich guy who gives his daughter absolutely anything she wants. And by anything I mean anything. He's at an extreme with his personality and so are all the other parents and their children. I get that this helps transmit an important message the film tries to send out: that some children are spoiled little brats, but the reality is that they are only a reflection of their own parents, I get it. But I think they could have made it more subtle and not so much "in your face" like in this movie. But that's pretty much it as a movie "flaw", but it takes a great part in the movie.Flaws aside, this movie is wonderful. It still looks amazing after nearly 45 years, the humor still holds up and it's just original as hell. Gene Wilder gives an iconic, hilarious performance that will NEVER be topped. Everything from the chocolate room with the chocolate river to the amazing songs in the movie feel magical. Another thing I love about this movie is the themes it handles. Like I mentioned earlier one of them is the raising kids to be spoiled brats theme and also what it means to be humble, like Charlie. The movie is so bizarre and even really scary at times, it is great.An amazing film, even if it has its flaws, they do not hide the fact that Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a film like no other and is, without a doubt, a classic.

reviews.review_title: The best movie of all time!
reviews.content: I absolutely love this movie! It was one of my favorites when I was a kid, and it's my favorite now, and I'm 18. Gene Wilder is definitely the best part of the entire movie. Even after I've seen it 50 million times, he still makes me laugh in all the same scenes. As a kid, I always loved it when Violet turned into a blueberry, and I thought that was so cool. I loved all the characters and their respective fates. I also loved the lickable wallpaper and wanted some just like it. This movie is total nostalgia for me, once I get started talking about it, I just go on and on, as you guys have already noticed. I can't get bored with it! This is definitely a classic, for children and adults.

reviews.review_title: The Bookers ( Texas) Most Watched Movie!!!
reviews.content: Love it ... Wonderful... Life Lessons ... Teaches Morals and Values!!!

The story tells a young boy named Charlie Bucket who, after finding a golden ticket in a chocolate bar, visit's Willy Wonka's chocolate factory along with four other children from around the world.I will say this one is a very cool movie and very classical. Roald Dahl who wrote the original novel hated this movie, calling it "crummy", he didn't like all the changes to the script and disliked the casts. I also found this better than the 2005 remake. Gene Wilder plays the quirky Wonka as he moralizes and cruelly punishes the little brats for their negative behaviors. Speaking of which, Wilder was not the first choice to play Wonka and he fits the mysterious character well. The song "Pure Imagination" has become a classic song and it has benefited my childhood and my love for candy. If you hadn't seen it then why wait and eat all the Wonka bars for such a delightful treat!9/10.

reviews.review_title: If SHE'S a lady, I'M a vernicious kanid!
reviews.content:
How well I remember my mom reading `Charlie & the Chocolate Factory' to me as I lay in bed with bronchitis or pneumonia as a youngster. Some time later, I took the book to school and my teacher (second, third, fourth grade? I can no longer recall which year) read it to the class, bit by bit.
When I saw the movie later, it seemed only a natural extension of the book. Both have remained favorites of mine. Although I have not read the book in at least 25 years, the movie is still very  enjoyable to me.I won't give a full-fledged review/analysis like I normally do. Suffice to say, it is still a classic. The cast is great, from veterans like Gene Wilder, Jack Albertson and Roy Kinnear, to the interesting group of child actors. Only Julie Dawn Cole (Veruca Salt) would go on to post anything that remotely resembled an acting career. Most never stood in front of a camera again, including the star, Peter Ostrum (Charlie), now a vet. Yet, considering the tragic lives of many child stars, this is certainly no unhappy ending for the kids. They each made their only film appearance a good one. The Oompa  Loompas were wonderful and had the best musical numbers in the movie. And, of course, the movie and book taught some lessons to parents and children, such as: don't be greedy, avoid nasty habits, don't spoil your kids, and don't fry your brain watching TV.The choice of Wilder to play Wonka was perfect. With the possible exception of Victor Frankenstein (FRONKenSTEEN), this WAS Wilder's role. He captures all the nuances that come with a Roald Dahl character and is charming in his little asides of Mr. Salt (Kinnear), Mrs. Tevee (Alice Ghostly clone  Dodo Denney) and others. The myriad of literary quotes added to Dahl's screenplay later lend a wonderfully detached, Alice in Wonderland feel to the film. When the Dahl in Wonka comes out (in the `cures' for the children who fell into mischief in the factory, etc.), it seems merely an extension of the bizarreness, rather than anything cruel. (Hope that's no spoiler!)Of course the nonsense language-again, a throwback to Alice in Wonderland-helps to promote this surreal feel, too, and results in some cute lines, like Grandpa Joe (Albertson)'s `If SHE'S a lady, I'M a vernicious kanid!'This is another of the great 1960s-early 1970s children's movies. Of course, as I've said in over reviews, I am a child of that era, and probably prejudiced. A child of ANY era (and an child at heart of any age) would love Willy Wonka, though. I hope watching Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory makes you go right out and read this review. WAIT! Strike that! Reverse it!

SICK SICK SICK, but either a sign of the times when such brazen brainwashing and homogenizing was the norm, or twisted-genius.  Akin to those identity-stealing `educational' (read: propaganda) shorts, they teach you that everything you do is wrong and you are only slightly LESS wrong by denying individuality.  One can only guess the true intent.Were the children cast as more villainous characters, one could almost rationally excuse and/or condone their ghastly fates.  But they were mainly just being kids with their typical personality quirks, which many of which grow out of with proper care.  And the so-called `hero' of the story is no less a meddlesome troublemaker, by the standards set by the other children, as illustrated in the bubble room.The lessons learned...?  No children can resist sin, and all of them are evil?  Affluence is evil?  Only poor kids are worthy of a second chance? Evil masquerades in bright colors, and sings funny songs?  Candy is bad?And that's just the underlying barely-subliminal wrong-messages (I didn't even touch the possible Freudian suggestions).  Some OBVIOUS red flags should be the glorification of an unchecked crazed despotic slave driver with Svengali-like control over children and the media, breaking the laws of nature and physics (and probably many other laws), housing a small personal army, and endangering children in hopes of finding an heir.Good grief, is there a SINGLE positive message?Most other children's movies and shows are drivel, but are far less harmless.  I wouldn't recommend this for ANY children you hope to grow up well adjusted.  I DO, however, recommend adults to watch this.  It's either a work of twisted-genius, or just a really bad kids movie.  Either way, it's fun to analyze.

I don't know how to tell how excited I am now. Dumb-dum-dumbbbbfounded... 173 comments on such well-researched IMDb webpages? Oh, I am so ignorant. Anyway, I should forgive myself because I am not living in the western world. I don't realize that the movie still attracts attention after all those years.The film was produced when I was two. Memory is something interesting, if it does not betray me, I should have seen it in 1975 or 1976 on TV in black and white. At that time, not many Hong Kong Chinese families could afford a colour TV. The Cantonese voice-over was done by a big team of talents voice professionals, one of them, a veteran, is named "Tam Ping Man".Vaguely the show left joyful feeling in my heart, that's the only thing I still keep. I didn't who know who Roald Dahl + Gene Wilder were (even I have watched "The Woman in Red" in 1984, I still didn't remember he was the eccentric owner of the chocolate factory). Then, around 20 years later in 1993, when David Tang of the world famous Shanghai Tang recommended this book for a local radio channel as one of the ten best books of that year, I suddenly recalled some scenes which matched his description. Everything then demystified.What was so powerful about this movie that I, who was only six or seven when I saw it for the first and only time, would keep those scenes in my mind? The success can be attributed to the luck Charlie Bucket got, the magic that his bedded grandparents suddenly could walk, the razzle-dazzle of the happy scenes with somersaults, delicious sweet chocolate and the happy young faces. No one can deny these elements attract not only young hearts but also the mature ones.I don't have any intention to see this old production again yet I am looking forward to the one which scheduled to be released in 2005 bearing exactly the same title of the book. Those were the kid days and it's gone, nostalgia is momentary, pressing forward is eternal.

reviews.review_title: Works on a number of different levels
reviews.content:
The only thing I really dislike about this film is the saccharinity - Charlie, Grandpa and the rest of his family combined with the whole 'perfect poor kid gets lucky' scenario. Oh, and some of the naffer musical numbers.
But, I realise that without this, they would never have got away with making the film. Look deeper, and you see the dark, satirical, hallucogenic fantasy world with no small amount of social commentary, a healthy dose of cynicism and - it has to be said - overtones of paedophilia, almost in the same vein as William Blake's Innocence/Experience poems.This will easily delight an audience of children or the elderly, and will hold their attention but the rest of us can see beyond the healthy family stuff, and watch this film for sheer escapsism value.Notice for example Gene Wilder's portrayal of the eccentric recluse - the beguiling stranger that kids are told never to talk to - and Julie Dawn Cole as spoiled brat verging on seductress. It's not just about interpretation either, I'm sure the film-makers knew exactly what they were doing.The morality tale that was at the core of Roald Dahl's novel is merely there to take the curse of an experimental and enjoyable film: take from it what you will.

This movie is well loved by kids and adults alike.It is one of the more successful adaptations of a book by Roald Dahl for the screen. Gene Wilder is great and the songs are just right to pad-out the story.Like most of Dahl's stories for kids there is a slightly dark ,cruel side running through the story but mostly it's fun and chocolate all the way through.Oh yeah, Jack Albertson as Grandpa Joe brought back fond memories of Chico And The Man. Great stuff.

I think the people on this website who call this movie "creepy" and "unsuitable for children" are the same people who insist on bleeping out the swears on television--which only serves to make them funnier. Calm down, people; I saw this when I was six years old, and watched it over and over throughout my childhood. It never scared me once, nor does it now.Now that I'm past my rant, I can honestly say that this is the best kids' movie I have ever seen. "Shrek" doesn't even come close. I own the soundtrack by Anthony Newley, and it's one of the best CD's I've ever bought. Willy Wonka will serve to entertain generations to come-as well it should.

Yes Gene Wilder does perform in a great lead role both singing as well as acting alike.As The Narrator for the Ad for this in The 1971 had even said The Things in this movie that Happen are incredible.As you watch for yourself you even get to as much enjoy this as you get to catch on to a # of things.Watch also for Jack Albertson as Grampa George and before he was made famous as Ed in "Chico and The Man."If you're familiar with the book before seeing this you can see the similarities too like when in this Veruca is a bad egg instead of a bad nut.The Egg-dicator of which she stands on is activated to dispense her for being a bad nut.Then her Father says "Wait Sweetheart Daddy is coming."Yes even though she'd been a headache to him all of the days of her life.Wanting everything but then after riding in Wonka's boat in conclusion changed her mind saying "Daddy I don't want a boat like this."In The Book Veruca was to The Squirrels a bad nut as they had found out after gnawing on her and so they then had dispensed with her.Just Watch The Movie called Charlie and the chocolate Factory and you'll see how it's more consistent to the book but that this is still even more enlightening and enjoyable.As I told for that film's review here on IMDb along with to also prove it went quickly to a 4 DVD pack.Truthfully,Stephen"Steve" G. A classic film from start to finish with gorgeous details, a fun cast, great lessons, and a hell of a good time. From chewing gum, to bad eggs, to transporters, this movie has it all for a fun family film.

This was a very cheesy film,I don't mean the food for all you cheese lovers,lol.Anyway this was terrible,It had old graphics,it didn't even have the title of the book.The actors were insane,I would rather watch ''Dumbo''.Charlie looked like a girl for petesake. I recommend the new & improved version directed by Tim Burton & composed by Danny Elfman. Johnny Depp was great and much better then Gene Wilder. Freddy Heighmore also did a better job in my opinion then the other actor who played Charlie in the 1971 version. The ompa loompa's were much better in this film. I feel they had more of a purpose in the new film,Deep Roy did a great job playing the ompa loompa's. Definitely go rent the 2005 film "Charlie & the Chocolate Factory" instead of this 1971 movie.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a timeless film with a masterful and magical story. It contains brilliant music, a range of colourful characters and an interesting story to boot.From fearful characters like Slugworth to the eccentric Wonka to the loveable Charlie Bucket, there is a lovely depth to all the characters here.There are moments of wonder such as the edible garden and moments of terror such as the boat ride.Classic.

After having just seen this film again tonight on ABC I must utter that most hackneyed of phrases: "they don't make movies like this anymore."
This movie speaks to children as well as the kid inside every adult. It doesn't talk down to kids and isn't afraid to be even a little frightening at times. Everything in the movie seems perfect: the script, the set, the songs, Gene Wilder, Jack Albertson, even the child actors. Only a jaded adult without an imagination would not enjoy this movie.And another thing. This is a story that isn't afraid to moralize a little. As Gene Wilder says in the documentary, the movie tells kids that there are limits, which is what they want and need.One gets the feeling that this movie was lovingly made. If you haven't viewed this movie in a while (or ever), do so. The DVD is an excellent transfer as well and looks every bit as good as the High Definition broadcast on Disney (ABC) I just saw. It is worth buying, even if you don't have kids.
The singing is superb. This movie is very good but it bullies children in it, which I don't mind but its something to take in consideration.

reviews.review_title: Looks More Realistic Than The 2005 Version
reviews.content: I used to really love Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory as a kid. This movie is a timeless movie that you can frequently find on TV, like ABC Family. It's interesting how a movie where the kids are from the Post World War 2 Baby Boom Generation, can appeal to the kids of the next generations. Comparing this film to the 2005 version, I only saw the 2005 version once. While the 2005 version seems to add more to the book, I liked this one better. I liked the kids better in the 2005 version as they're kids from my generation. However, while watching the 2005 version I felt like it looked less realistic, the chocolate and scenery being from special effects, and the factory in the 2005 version looked so unrealistically huge. Watching this 1971 one, the way they show the factory looks more like a realistic Willy Wonka's factory than the 2005 one, even the scenery around the factory and gadgets. The 2005 one seemed more like entering a fictional virtual world from how I remember it. Also, I think Gene Wilder plays a more realistic version of Willy Wonka than Johnny Depp. The characters in this one also seem more realistic than the characters in the 2005 version. This movie often times frequently has references from it, like I frequently see pictures online of Willy Wonka during the Everlasting Gobstopper scene with some message. So, this movie has stood the test of time. While it's been awhile since I've seen it, I still think of it as an enjoyable movie to watch and I feel like everybody deserves to see Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory at least once.

reviews.review_title: One of the all time best
reviews.content: Gene Wilder in one of his best roles is perfect as the enigmatic slightly insane Wonka. Jack Albertson later of Chico and The Man is another standout playing Grandpa Joe. One of my favourite parts of this movie is the comic asides from the parents as they go on the tour... "there he goes again!" ..." she's a nitwit" etc. Also the vignettes the director adds for other people searching for the ticket, in particular the woman who has to stop and ponder whether or not her kidnapped husband is worth given up a case of Wonka bars. Great colour, great songs. Not a dull scene in the entire running time.

Wilder is Scary, funny, rude, sadistic, warm , apathetic and many more things in this film. He was too young for the part and nobody noticed. I actually saw this one in the Movies twice. It was only out for a week or two in 71 when  saw it the first time. It was re-released a few years later when I enjoyed it again. I always have to make sure there's candy bars in the house when I watch this classic.

It is hilariously condescending, sarcastic, and punny. The tone is whimsical yet grounded, and the world building is carefully crafted. My only complaint is it takes 40 minutes to get to the chocolate factory. Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory is a pop culture phenomenon. A timeless classic that transcends generations.

This movie was generally okay. Nothing amazing, nothing surprising. I guess I particularly liked Violet, the gum-chewing maniac. This movie isn't necessarily one I'd reccommend. It misses the mark, but it's not the worst of the game. After all, it has Oopmaloompa's, doesn't it??

This was my favorite live action movie as a kid. I positively loved all the colors, all the fantasy, and most of all, all the candy. Well, except for the candy, I still have pretty much the same opinion of it as I had then. Now, though, I appreciate it even more, having read the book and grown old enough to understand the more subtle jokes. I also think now that Gene Wilder was a perfect Willy Wonka. He played the perfect weird genius. I can see why people were afraid of it as kids, with all the weird stuff that happened to the bad kids and everything. However, I was raised on Disney movies and the like, not the horror movies "Willy Wonka" has been compared to, and I still liked it, so I wouldn't say it's unsafe for all kids to see. I would recommend that those who were afraid of it as kids see it again now for the good in it they may have missed out on then.

reviews.review_title: It's a classic... but not for everyone
reviews.content: This movie is interesting. I laughed out loud at a couple of parts and then found myself quite puzzled in other parts. I like the first part of the movie. I actually don't care as much for the parts at the chocolate factory. I like Gene Wilder but it was a bit odd at those parts with the Oompa Loompa people singing so much... creepy!

reviews.review_title: An affront to the book and absurd to boot
reviews.content:
Sure, if you have good memories of watching this as a kid, you'll see it with rose-colored goggles, but the movie is really bad. The acting is terrible, especially by the main character Willy Wonka himself, the additions of characters like Slughorn are unnecessary, and in the end, Charlie wins it all even though he and grandpa Joe were as bad as the other children!
Roald Dahl himself was so upset at this movie's adaptation of his book that he demanded in his will that no more Willy Wonka books be made into movies. That should tell you how terrible this film is.

reviews.review_title: Better than the book, but still not that good...
reviews.content: I think most of America, at least, has seen this movie. It's considered a classic in our society and a rite of passage for every American kid. I obviously have seen this movie but I thought it was only just OK. I thought the book was worse but the movie is far from great. The scenes with the Wonka-obsessed adults I thought were presented in a way that was hard for children to understand. I felt like I was watching an adult movie. I have to say this for the book: it did a better job in that department. If anything, this movie wasn't a very good adaptation. Plus, I thought it was a little out-of-character when Wonka blew up at Charlie and his grandpa. That was another element I thought was too grown-up. However, this movie has its winning points. I'm glad that unlike the book, the kids brought one parent each instead of both of them. That makes for less crowding. I also like how they added in Slugworth and his everlasting gobstopper test. All in all, this is just an OK movie. Its atmosphere was just a little too bizarre for my taste. It's still better than the book and mildly enjoyable to watch.

A great children's classic, made in the days when it was okay to frighten the kids a little (not through violence, but through psychedelic disorientation and uncertainty).  The Oompa Loompas scared me when I was four years old, and they have the same effect on me even now.  Something especially about their blank, unenthusiastic faces as they plod through their moral finger-wagging ditties.  Was Willy Wonka guilty of rampant exploitation and labor abuses?  The Oompa Loompas were always WORKING, and clearly none too pleased about it.

Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory can be summed up in one word: Magical. The movie is pure magic and very underrated here on the database and across the general film community. A true family classic. The effects they used were very modern and intriguing for it's time and that's only one element that makes this movie so fantastic. There is fantastic music, characters, actors and very quotable dialog. I couldn't of asked another living soul to play Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka, he was born to play Willy Wonka and he delivered fantastically. Overall it's a feel-good magical family movie with a hidden message that became an instant classic and upholds as one of the best tales ever told on film.

I remember the first time that I saw this movie was at a drive in theater. My father spent most of the time outside the car with a friend of his drinking beer having never been a fan of fantasy and subsequently reported to my mother that the film was stupid.I, of course, did not find it so. It is one of my most wonderful memories from childhood, and the sheer delight that I get from watching it remains when I watch it even today.I read the "Charlie" books after this, but I have to confess it is the movie that sticks in my head. I will always see Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka and Jack Albertson as Grandpa Joe. I loved the song "Pure Imagination" and have used it to inspire myself from time to time through out my life. I think this film to a pleasant diversion that everyone should take.

reviews.review_title: It is my all time favourite.
reviews.content: It was too good but Mr Willy Wonka was a bit scary.I did not know that Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory was such an old film.It's actually bigger than my big brother who is going to be 30 in November.The character who played Charlie was just too good.The new Charlie and the chocolate factory was great too but like they say old is gold.I really love this movie so much that I can watch it anytime as it is my old time favourite.Charlie and the chocolate factory is the story about a poor boy,Charlie Bucket who finds a golden ticket to see the wonderful chocolate and sweets maker,Mr Willy Wonka and because Charlie is a polite that he wins the whole Chocolate factory because Willy Wonka is to old and does not trust any of the kids that also found a golden ticket because they are greedy.

I have a confession to make. I didn't like the 191 Mel Stuart film. Now, before you come and attack me, let me just say that I am NOT forcing you to hate it, but I want you to actually UNDERSTAND how I feel about it.I'm aware it's been referenced in popular culture, and yes, I did love Wonka candies as a kid, but that doesn't mean I'm gonna like the movie. Even if I didn't read the original Roald Dahl book, it did not feel like the book this movie was based on.It's just a feature length commercial for Wonka candies. No wonder Roald Dahl hated the movie. It was such an insult to his hit book, it received poor reviews upon its release, and bombed at the box office for good reason. The writing is too play it safe. The acting (even with such talent) is dry. The sets are fake. The chocolate river isn't even real chocolate. Slugworth isn't needed. The fizzy lifting drinks are wasted and unnecessary. And while most of the songs are fine on their own, they don't fit the Roald Dahl tone of the story.The Oompah Loompah song got very annoying after four times. I'm sure it's not as bad as the version with Tom and Jerry, but I didn't laugh once at this movie. Not to mention that the characters in the movie are poorly written. I honestly prefer the Tim Burton version of the movie, because it's a lot closer to the original book than this.

People are fond of saying "the book was better," particularly when they haven't read it but strive to sound erudite. In this case, it's true: by providing more detailed anecdotes expressive of Willy Wonka's encyclopedic knowledge base and earth-shattering sense of humor, the book scores eleven whilst the movie scored only ten. We all know how talented Wilder is--particularly, when he writes, not only when he acts, witness the astonishing creativity of "Young Frankenstein." This movie provided a vehicle for Wilder to sing, dance, jest, wisecrack, and even display the rare dramatic moment, typically centered around the emotion of love (even when seemingly busting on some child's self-imposed torment, e.g., blowing up like a blueberry or being micro-miniaturized during electromagnetic transport). Even Jack Albertson got a chance to sing and dance, but--as you may not have been aware--there was a time when a (young) Jack Albertson was nationally renowned as a soft-shoe dancer and vaudevillian. I frankly think that Charlie could have been better cast in a less humdrum figure than Peter Ostrum: certainly, he did not rise to the level of brilliant characterization that we discern in, say, Mike Teevee or Veruca Salt (BTW, quite apropos, as 'verruca' is Latin for 'wart'). This is one of my favorite movies of all time. Plus, the occasional quotes from classic English writers are immortal: "We are the music-makers, and we are the dreamers of dreams," or perhaps, "Where is fancy bred? // In the heart, or in the head?" Bravo, Gene!

reviews.review_title: My all-time favorite movie-and one of the few from my childhood to *truly* hold up!
reviews.content: This film-along with the book, and the others also by Roald Dahl-was my obsession when I was in second grade. Dahl himself described his success as a children's storyteller by saying he "sided with children against adults", and perhaps that is why I loved it so much at an age when I was very angry at most of the adults in my life. (Though in retrospect, perhaps reading comprehension wasn't my strength-I embodied all the negative characteristics of the four "bad" kids in one package!).The film's story is directed and told with simplicity, which is how it should be. Even the ending that differs from the book suits the material in a way that is unique to cinema. Unlike modern-day films, the special effects necessary to create the illusions in the film are kept at a minimum, which leads us to view them not as special effects, but as "real" events, no matter how fantastic (compare the famous "big blueberry" scene in this film with its counterpart in the Tim Burton version, and you'll see what I mean).The protagonist, Charlie (Peter Ostrum) is not given a whole lot to do in any version of this story, especially when compared with Wonka himself (the late, great Gene Wilder in his best performance) and the other kids, but this allows us to project and imagine ourselves as Charlie, and thus the story is stronger for it. Among the kids, the standout character in both the book and the film is Veruca Salt, played by Julie Dawn Cole, and she is a certifiable scene thief indeed. Now, I have had this film memorized for close to twenty-five years, but every time she makes demands of her "daddy" (Roy Kinnear), I can't stop cracking up, just as I did when I was eight.The music is also wonderful, though not entirely true to the tone of Dahl's book-however, the film compensates for it. "Pure Imagination" in particular is beautiful, especially in how the scene is staged. In a more typical musical, the song would've been treated as a bravura show-stopper that would've detracted from whatever sense of reality the film would've conveyed up to that point. Instead, the scene is underplayed, allowing the melody to set the stage for the scene without overpowering it. The pauses between lines allow for some delicious character details for both Wonka and the kids, not interrupting the momentum at all as it might seem. The slow pace of the song floods us with the mood intended. (I understand Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley, the authors of the music, were opposed to this interpretation of the song-ironic, given how this turned out to be one of the most memorable scenes in the film).Most films from my childhood, I can look back on with some distance and say "Yeah, the film itself isn't that great, but the memories of watching it color it for me so that I can still kinda see it as I did then". Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is an exception-when I reviewed it last night for the purpose of writing about it, it had the same power on me that it did when I first saw it in 1994.I'll end on an unusual sidenote of the dual nature of the screenplay. The first time I heard the opera "The Marriage of Figaro" by Mozart, the very first thing I noticed was that the opening notes of the overture were, in fact, the notes played by Wonka to open the "musical lock" on the Chocolate Room door in this film, and I couldn't help but giggle. "Rachmaninoff," says Mrs. Teavee in the scene, incorrectly. The film assumes that we know she is wrong, thus assuming the best about the viewer-much more than it would've had a more familiar melody been used. And that, truly, is the most valuable thing about the film-it approaches the audience as if it is intelligent, perhaps more than it should...

reviews.review_title: There is no life I know to compare with pure imagination
reviews.content:
* * * * (4 out of 5)
Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory
Directed by: Mel Stuart, 1971
"There is no life I know to compare with pure imagination. Living there, you'll be free if you truly wish to be." - Willy Wonka, [singing]
The endearing tale of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory brought to life. Mostly for kids, while adults may find Gene Wilder both dark and funny. Timeless in spirit, not in style (looks are dated, contains loads of sappy songs), Willy Wonka still surprises with its sharpness and relentlessness towards moral issues. Wilder is brilliant (a bit nasty for the youngest; "Candy is dandy, but liquor is quicker"), the pace is fast and surprising, and the chocolate factory sets are still amazing.
