reviews.review_title: An allegory for first world exploitation of the underclass.
reviews.content: This movie has never ceased to disturb me.  First as a child and now as a 25 year old adult.  To this day, the boat ride scene showcasing Gene Wilder's penchant for maniacal song and psychadelic freak-outs gives me the willies, so to speak.  I've never had a bad acid trip, or any acid trip for that matter, but I'm sure that that scene is the synthesis of such misfortune and has, as a side effect, kept me away from the use of hallucinogens.As far as the actual story goes, I think it has nothing to do with a handful of children learning life lessons at a very dear price.  Perhaps on the surface it teaches children to not gorge themselves on bratwurst and the flows of chocolate rivers, or to not chew gum and watch excessive amounts of tv.  Couched within these preachy morale narratives is a deeper message; one which puts on display the excesses of the modern world, more specifically the first world and it's exploitation of the third.  I'd like to expound on this further, but honestly, nobody cares and I'm at work, so I've already over extended myself as it is. I'm just doing this to hear myself type anyway, maybe I'll add more later.

reviews.review_title: Arguably the best family movie ever made
reviews.content: A treat from start to finish.  Gene Wilder is brilliant as the eccentric Willy Wonka, and despite the (now) primitive special effects, the chocolate factory is as wondrous today as ever.  Watchable over and over again.  I give it a strong 9.

reviews.review_title: How can they re-make this film?
reviews.content: This 1971 children's film is a classic. It's funny, fun, mysterious, and even a little scary. The performances are wonderful, the music is timeless, and it is quite a good rendition of the classic book by Roald Dahl, granted Mr. Dahl wrote the screenplay. Now a re-make of the classic film is slated to be shot. I find this hard to believe-- just like re-making Psycho-- what is the point? Re-making films in the era of video and DVD seems silly. In the earlier days of films, the older versions were not readily available for the public, so it seemed fine to re- introduce the world to the stories, but now I just don't understand the point in re- making films that are classics. The new one may be a fine rendition-- I have faith that Johnny Depp is fully capable of playing a wonderful Willy Wonka, but it's a role that I think was already extremely well portrayed by Gene Wilder. What a magical movie this is, what a wonderful story-- every child should see Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, the original, the classic...

What a great movie! Gene Wilder was awesome as Wonka, and the original movie is a kids classic. Now there is a new movie coming out directed by Tim Burton. He makes such interesting movies and is a creative director, but I wonder why he couldn't have moved forward with one of the other Wonka stories. Certainly Johnny Depp is an "odd enough" and versatile actor to play the recluse of Wonka, but would have much preferred they left Charlie & The Chocolate Factory for Wilder and let Depp play Wonka on The Great Glass Elevator. Still, will go see the new movie and see how Burton has "darkened" the Wonka character. I'm hoping it will still be a lite enough movie for younger kids, but am guessing this will not be the case. If you get a chance, check out the trailer by doing a net search for the new movie.
Nice for younger people also for older people like me. George Bush you can say it.

reviews.review_title: Good movie, but less faithful to the book then you'd expect
reviews.content: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory was a good movie, but it is not faithful to the book, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Davis Seltzer(who I suspect wrote the shooting script, because R.D. said that he didn't like the final script), did too many changes to it. For instance, the Oompa-Loompas sang really bad songs "Oompa-Loompa do-pe-de-dah, I got another puzzle for you", was one of them. If you want to see movie versions of other Dahl books, you should see the way-more faithful movie versions of James and the Giant Peach and Matilda. Although this is a good family film(in line with Star Wars and E.T.), it is a bad adaption of a great, fun book.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory was the best film adaption of a Dahl book. The Witches were bad, and these two are the most famous ones. If you liked the book, you will really like this movie! Or, in reverse(but I read the book first, so, I don't know what you think).

This movie is tell all of every child's dream. To not only go to what is marveled, in the movie, all over the world by each and every child who eats candy, but to WIN the place too? Hello!! Win it because you found a dollar in the gutter, amidst on being down in the dumps because you of all people really, really love WIlly Wonka candy. Then, to be put into a position to screw him over when you think you're getting the shaft, and to NOT do it because you admire and respect everything this chocolate maker does is an incredible story line. But that's not all, because you were so true to your beliefs, you now OWN the factory yourself. How awesome is this? Put that together with the line of all movie lines... "Charlie, did you hear about the boy who suddenly got everything he wanted? He lived happily ever after." Hallmark moment!!! NO matter how old you are, this movie has the storyline and sub-plots for you. Enjoy!

Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is one of my family's favourite books so we were keen to see the film version. Whatever happened to Mr Bucket?  Charlie's Dad worked in a toothpaste factory, screwing the caps on the tubes. Was this form of employment considered so menial that he was written out of the story? And Charlie's mother was not a washerwoman!  As regards her singing, this could have been omitted... The kids, instead, are just as we imagined them: thoroughly disgusting, except hero Charlie of course.  Gene Wilder is the perfect Mr Willy Wonka. The Oompah-Loompahs are maybe not quite what we imagined, but they were very effective.  Their songs are far more memorable than Mrs Bucket's sloppy effort.

I was seventeen the first time I came across this movie a few years ago. First I didn't like it, much for the same reason people have labeled this movie traumatising and sadistic for kids. I agree to a point. Had I been ten years younger I would've been really frightened by this movie, especially by the tunnel scene. And yes, it is somewhat dark. After seeing it a couple more times however, I came to like it more and more, and now it's one of my favorite movies. Why? Because it 'hits the spot' in every way a children's movie should.It's about a poor little boy who gets to live out the dream of every kid in the world. There's a choco-river, humor, music, fun props, candy, enough to make even an adult's imagination run wild. WWACF is an enjoyable escape from reality, and is actually very well made. Adults can also pick out the brilliant humor imbedded in the dialog.Apart from a few unnecessary songs and questionable scenes, Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory is a great classic. Highly recommended for everyone, except sensitive little kids.

reviews.review_title: The film that is as good as the day it was made.
reviews.content: I watched this film again after nearly twenty years, and became emotional, both at its objective quality and at the powerful memories it evoked. Beautifully filmed, directed, cast, scripted and choreographed, it is as good as it ever was, while maintaining the omnipresent edge of danger which was such an important part of the book. As suitable for adults as children. I think the name change (to 'Willy Wonka and ...' from 'Charlie and ...') was because the story of the film had some radical differences from the book, particularly in Charlie's discovery of the golden ticket and the film's ending, and not least because the film was set in the U.S.A., while the book was in England. In my opinion the changes were an improvement, creating a snappier and more credible storyline.The music is infectious; from the days before computer assisted music, the film had to use an orchestra - all the better for it. Diana Sowle's solo, 'Cheer Up Charlie' is another feature of what has, through all those years, remained such a delightful film.

reviews.review_title: The common names of the adults
reviews.content: Has anyone noticed that in the movie all the adult couples have common names; Grandpa Joe and Grandma Josephine, Grandpa George and Grandma Georgette, Veruca's parents, Henry and Henrietta. I always thought that was kind of interesting. This movie is so great. I do agree in some ways that it is more of an adult film with all the satire involved. I also wonder what did Charlie's Grandparents do about using the restroom if they occording to Charlies Mom had not been out of the bed in twenty years. Wonka says to Charlie at the end of the movie that only an adult could take over the factory because an adult would want to do things his own way. Plus I think that Wonka pre chose the winners, how else would Mr Sluggworth know were all the winners were as soon as they found the golden tickets???

reviews.review_title: One of the Greatest Films Ever
reviews.content: Definitely the greatest children's film of all time and possibly one of the best films ever. Gene Wilder's terrific sarcasm and numerous poetic allusions makes him a joy to watch. The entire movie is just incredible

This film was adorable, and I have seen this film since I was at least 3 years old. Sometimes, this film makes me starve because, the candy was so delicious! The scenes were all right, but unfortunately, there was a problem: TECHNICAL ERROR: In the blueberry segment, the hose was present by Violet's (Nickerson) ankle. The hose was used, to inflate her body to transform to a blueberry, and I possibly think that they used special clothing when they had to roll her, to be squeezed before she explodes. I believe, that it was a scary line to remember. Funny quote: "I've got a blueberry, for a daughter!"--whimpers.....Veruca, is a bad egg!!! and too offensive!!!. Overall, this film was so adorable, and it was good film to watch!!!I give it 1,000,000 blueberries!!!

Classified as a children's movie, it really has a dark edge more appropriate for adults.  Starts slowly, but I'll never forget when I first saw the main room in the chocolate factory. Spectacualr Eye Candy! The songs are good too.  Gene Wilder is great as Wonka and the child actors are good as well. I love the story of a poor boy who wins the chance of a lifetime.  The bad eggs (especially Veruca) get their comeuppance.  But I really can't explain why this is my favorite movie!  It just has this je ne sais quoi that makes it so great!

The previous review mentioned about a mental health factor.  I think I was scarred for life, how those orange-skinned Oompah's kept on taking kids away one by one after singing some sort of tribal chant, and you never saw that kid again.   To this day, I get chills whenever I see that movie on TV...

There's a reason this childrens classic has endured, and it's visible on the beautiful new DVD, ripe with extra fun features. I hadn't seen it for years, but the songs and the acting are all just wonderful. Deserves to be on the same list as The Wizard of Oz, it's that good. If you have any children near you, grab this film and stick it in. Even though it was apparently made for a dime, it has heart and soul that the biggest  Harry Potter budget can't buy.

reviews.review_title: 100% Family Entertainment from start to finish
reviews.content: Fantastical books, particularly children's books, can be daunting to show on the big screen. This film is so well done, that any plot divergences can be overlooked when the overall effect is so magnificent, as it is here. Considering that beyond Gene Wilder and Roy Kinnear, this is a cast of little-knowns, it shows what a great script can do for any cast, given the belief in it. The designs are superb, both inside and outside the factory, there is almost every kind of comedy, from verbal to visual, and the dramatic device involving deception (and a certain sweet) is almost secondary to the wild adventure which Charlie Bucket undergoes. I thoroughly enjoyed this film as a child, and as an adult, it loses none of its charm. Also, the ending is not disappointing. Which perhaps means that it is a fairytale after all.

I think it's fantastic! I especially liked the songs like,"The Candyman","I have a golden ticket","If you want a way to view Paradise","Come on Charlie" etc. I also liked the way slugs-worth pretended to be a spy, but really he was Willi's helper!Willi was really funny. I liked this movie more than the new movie.I also liked the sound of Mike Tevee's lisp,it sounded really cute!I think the man who created it must have a really big imagination! The Oompaloompas looked so funny I fell out of my chair laughing!I also liked the way the Oompaloompas sang their song,their funny tall green hair and their cute orange little faces.

Frankly, I was glad to see that the execution of the chicken was gone from the background of the boat trip as shown on the DVD. In earlier videotapes and even seeing the actual film projected on a screen, the killing of the chicken was considered something that should never have been included. Actually, the removal of the execution of the chicken made the whole film so much more enjoyable. I laughed, I cheered, I thoroughly enjoyed the production from beginning to end. Knitting: Kudos need to go to the little lady who was sitting up in bed and knitting striped socks, a red scarf, and a hat for Charlie. I knit, and one day I hope to make a replica of the hat, if anything.

I just saw this movie again recently when it was shown at a local theater - and fell in love with it again. However, as an adult, I was surprised to see how sadistic the movie can be - kids die in a number of ways. Nothing violent or gory, mind you - but still unusual for a "children's movie". Comparing it to Seven, as some reviewers have done (kids die for their sins) is a large stretch.That being said, this film is just pure, pre- packaged imagination. It is a visual treat, and Wilder's performance is perfect. As a child I wasnt able to enjoy the bitter sarcasm he presents. He's hysterical! The movie is as magical as I remember it from my childhood.It's a sweet movie both kids and adults will love, for the same and different reasons.

Im not a big fan of singing and dancing. But this movie brings it out in everyone. After I got the DVD of this film, it quickly became my practice that at the end of a bad week, I'd come home on Friday, put it on, and watch the world's worries leave. I'm a great fan of escapism, and this film is the best thing I've ever found to help me achieve it. No matter what happened that week, on the weekend i can dance all day, whistling away.The scene in this movie that best sums up its effect is "Pure Imagination". Children running everywhere in a room filled with sweets - any child's dream. And that is why this film is so perfect. It shows us all our childhood dreams come true for Charlie, allows for that little while to believe it could happen to us. But more importantly this film, and especially this scene, shows us life through a child's eyes, full of wonder. If that doesn't cheer you up, there is something wrong with you.

Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory its simply Magical!! When i first saw this movie as a child i was really impressed i loved the movie since then. When you see the movie it gives you like special powers to love. I really recommend this movie to all of the IMDB members you wont regret it. By the way to bad Warnerbrothers only released the pan and scan format, ive heard many persons complain about this but to me it dosent matter i will always love and remember this movie.

reviews.review_title: There is no life I know to compare with Pure Imagination
reviews.content: "You can never never doubt what no one is sure about." "So much time and so little to do, what a minute, strike that revers it." This movie is so clever with such wonderful quotes and songs. Part of you is scarred of Willy Wonka, but yet you want to be his best friend.  A wonderful movie.

A lot of the comments on this movie center around the so-called disturbing aspects of the Wonka factory. Oompah Loompahs have been called creepy, Wonka is lambasted as sadistic, etc.When this film came out, I was eight years old. Other than the images projected on the tunnel wall as the boat went through, I didn't find anything particularly scary. Mostly it sparked my imagination and made me laugh.In my opinion, this was the best "children's" film of my generation. It wasn't until _Babe_ that a children's film of comparable quality was released. (Not surprising, _Babe_ was criticized by some for being too disturbing for children.)

A fabulous, wild ride.  I've seen it dozens of times and still enjoy every moment.  A morals lesson, an honesty lesson.  It's good, wholesome entertainment for children and adults alike.  This happens to be my favorite movie of ALL time.

Since I am a card carrying chocoholic, I rank this as one of my favorite movies of all time, except I am very jealous of those kids. If I had been there I probably would have gone for the chocolate river just like Agustus. Reading some of the other comments I was puzzled that some people say that it is a terrifying movie. I saw it when I was around 10 and I wasn't terrified at all. Some people even mention something about children being killed, but none of the children die. It makes me wonder what movie they were watching.

****SPOILER WARNING*****I read from someone else on here that they too noticed the part showing the chicken getting its poor head cut off in this, of all things, a children's movie. I thought I was the only one who noticed that and I still can't believe it every time I see it. What in hell possessed them to include that in the film? I heard there were some interesting scenes shot for this movie that were scrapped because I guess when they showed them to a test audience, the audience didn't laugh when they were supposed to laugh so they left out the scenes...I think one was something about a traveller going to see an old wise man guru and the punch line was, "Life is a disappointment"...anyway, even if these scenes did not work, I sure wish they would release them in a special edition of this movie with unseen footage-it would be facinating to see. Characters were great-I loved the school teacher, Veruca Salt, Violet, and Charlie's mother especially, and Gene Wilder was perfect for the role! I just think they shouldn't have included the chicken part.

reviews.review_title: Gene Wilder is great in this
reviews.content: The movie's plot is about the titular Willy Wonka who owns a mysterious chocolate factory that nobody can have access to. Soon, Wonka announces that there is a contest that involves people buying his chocolate bars and finding golden tickets hidden inside. The winner receives a tour of his strange factory, but since there are only 5 tickets in the entire world, it's way easier said than done. A modest boy named Charlie is the story's unlikely protagonist, he is humble enough to not let the temptation of finding a golden ticket control his life. He doesn't expect to find one, and his family is much more important to him than a bunch of candy. As time goes by, the golden tickets start getting discovered by lucky children from various locations around the world, but the kids who win are all spoiled and don't really deserve them. A gluttonous German kid named Augustus is the first winner, followed by Veruca Salt, Violet Beauregarde, and Mike Teevee. Finally, Charlie manages by pure luck to find a ticket after the original fifth winner is proved to be a fake. Out of all the children who win, Charlie is the only decent one that doesn't have a snarky, in-your-face attitude, and it makes the audience sympathize with him. The rest of the movie involves Charlie being taken on a tour (along with the other children) of Wonka's factory while he is chaperoned by his formerly bedridden grandfather. Wonka shows them all kinds of strange candy related things, from waterfalls made of melted chocolate to drinks that allow the consumer to float. There's a shocking false ending where Charlie, as the only remaining member of the tour after all the other kids have been eliminated, asks Wonka about the promised lifetime supply of chocolate, and Wonka tells him he's not getting any as he "broke the rules" by stealing the lifting drinks. Charlie's grandfather suggests to Charlie he should get even with Wonka by giving the recipes for some of his secret Candy to his adversary Slugworth, but Charlie returns the gobstopper to Wonka instead. As it turns out, this whole part was just a test of morals that only Charlie was decent enough to pass, and Wonka tells Charlie that his family now has legal ownership over his factory. The performances in this movie are all amazing, especially Wilder's, and he was without a doubt the best Willy Wonka ever.

"Come with me and you'll be in a world of pure imagination" as we are guided through the Wonka Factory by the unpredictable Willy Wonka showing that anything is possible with some imagination. A fantastic family musically film filled with inspiration and imagination that everyone would enjoy even with the dark tone. A wonderful adaptation from Roald Dahl (personally he despise the movie)a great cast, wonderful soundtrack good storyline makes a movie worth watching.Willy Wonka thought off a great marketing ploy by opening his factory to the winners of the 5 golden tickets and a lifetime supply of Wonka bars. Wonkamania begins everybody wanted one,as the golden tickets are found we see that the kids except Charlie won are brats. The second half is about Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory hence the title name.The fine-line of genius and insanity is blurred with Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka and his only role Peter Ostrum as Charlie the innocent kid. The movie is directed by Mel Staurt and was release back in 1971 so it is a classic and filmed in Technicolor.The entire movie most of the color were muted except the color red a few other color but mostly bright red (Charlie sweater).Not only the characters and the wonderful props but the original musical score brings another aspect to this magical movie. Composed by Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley it was nominated for Best Original Score back in 1972.It is indeed a musical with catchy musical numbers and inspiring songs with a message behind it. Starting with the opening credit to the ending credit an instrumental of Pure Imagination sets the tone.  There are some dark tone like the how world obsession with chocolate early on (Wonkamania)and the tunnel scene which Gene Wilder did a great performance that people on the set though he went crazy by being in the tunnel. It seems that Willy Wonka planned on getting rid of the kids throughout the film and what really happen to the kids when they disappeared? Overall a musical about imagination and inspiration with a little bit of insanity making it worth watching many times.Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory shows a possibility of joy for a poor boy. So what happen to the boy who suddenly got everything he alway wanted? He lived happily ever after. Take the main lyrics and apply it to life."We are the music maker and we are the dreamers of dream".

This is an awesome movie. I recall seeing it in the theater as a kid and have loved it ever since. There is something disturbing that I have noticed lately and is what I call the Grandpa Joe Quandary. I dearly loved Grandpa Joe as a kid but now he seems less likeable and selfish. Lets look at the facts. He lay in bed for 20 years while Charlie's mom worked like a slave to keep them all in poverty. His only luxury was a bowl a week. I wish I had that much!! At one point he gives Charlie a Wonka bar and everyone is mystified as to where he got it. He said he quit smoking but if the young slave in training Charlie nor his Mother purchased it, who then?. Perhaps there is more to Grandpa Joe's sinister side. When Charlie finally does get the golden ticket, Grandpa Joe is not only the first to stake his claim to it but can mystically rise from the bed in which he has been imprisoned for the last 20 years. Within minutes he can sing, dance and run around. Perhaps greed is the driving factor. i.e. "I've got a golden ticket" not we have a golden ticket. Listen to this key evidence and you will realize that Grandpa Joe is seemingly only in it for himself. Not once does he offer to care for the elders while Charlie and his Mom go to the factory. Grandpa does have a need to indulge his perverse side when convincing Charlie to steal Fizzie Lifting Drinks as well, knowing the potential outcome of this crime. Perhaps this was his way of training Charlie for his future, whatever that may have been if it were not for Willy Wonka. Grandpa Joe is quick to foul mouth Mr. Wonka when confronted with his improprieties and eager to join Slugworths minions at the first sign of trouble.

reviews.review_title: How anyone can prefer the new film is beyond me...
reviews.content: This is in my opinion the greatest musical of all time and I am sure that I am not the only person that thinks this. Pure Imagination is a classic, so is Candyman, cheer up Charlie even I want it now is brilliant. It is wonderful, magical and there is no other film like it, including the new film. I would give the new one 2 out of 10 as it is a disgrace to the old version. Just because Roald Dahl didn't like this film it does not mean he would like that one. Gene Wilders performance is spectacular. This is the classic and it can't be beaten by any crappy performance by any actor no matter how famous. Each song is the equivalent (sorry for spelling!) of the best song in any other musical.

reviews.review_title: classic, funky modern fairytale and fable
reviews.content:
All the greatest children's stories are slightly dark and feature a maniacal hero that only kids can accept without applying cynicism. This Roald Dahl story is far less cruel and sadistic than the book, unfortunately, yet still transports you into a magical world of fantasy. Both a modern fairytale and trippy fable, this is a film that I watched on rotation as a child. It both speaks to, and awakens your imagination, and now as a young adult, it is still one of my favourite films, and it's moralistic approach always has me returning the metaphorical everlasting gob-stopper.Made in 1971, this film is definitely a product of its time. Colourful and highly kitsch, I can just imagine a flat of students,  sitting down to watch this as a fail-safe cosmic experience. The scene with the hallucinogenic tunnel is scary when you are little, the Ooompa Loompa's, amusing, yet when you get older, they both become equally terrifying and yet incredibly captivating and call out to a part of you that you thought had fallen asleep when you hit puberty.Gene Wilder excels as he plays a pure caricature of an eccentric magician with a sky-high intellect and equally vast plans for his golden ticket winners. This is not an easy task, but is executed with complete style - a totally classic performance. Veruca Salt's dreams of a bean feast are also a delight everytime. Julie Dawn Cole expertly plays the role of psychotic exorcist-style' brat from hell with a twinkle in her eye and a sardonic smile. This child of Satan also went on to provide a name for a rather average but fun band, as well as perhaps demonstrating the first signs of dangerous girl power to a generation of Spice Girl parents.
Each stage of the film is memorable, playing with your mind and teasing the senses. That is the beauty of this film. Suspend all rationality and ignore the messy confines of logic. Instead, look into yourself and be reminded that the most important thing to be, is a good person. Or something like that. That, and it is always good to eat a lot of artificially coloured confectionery.

reviews.review_title: One of the Best? Wrong. The best.
reviews.content: It's a crazy movie with even crazier characters.  And that alone makes it more realistic than most of us realize.  We all have some aspect of each of these characters inside us.  Both the greedy kids and their equally greedy parents are unfortunately just like us.  However, there is hope for our world because inside each of us is a bit of the virtuous Charlie, struggling to succeed.But Willy Wonka is the truly magical character of this movie.  He has the creative mind and flamboyant nature that we all have, but rarely show.  He lives in a paradise of his own creation.  He lets his imagination and desires dictate what he does, without succumbing to the sin of greed.But this is all subtly delivered to you.  You don't have to analyze this movie to enjoy it.  You have so many fantastic characters that parallel the school teachers, news reporters, psychologists, and scientists of the world to laugh at again and again.It's a movie of two halves: The first is the outside world where five golden tickets are found.  The second is the fantasy world of the Chocolate Factory where imagination comes to life.  What this movie does so well is combine the two worlds, suggesting we add more fantasy and creativity to our repetitve and greedy everyday lives.  Use your mind to warm the world up, so you can get out of bed without worrying about a cold floor.

reviews.review_title: Compare ye not the book and the film.
reviews.content: Roald Dahl is an author many adults find unsettling. They hate the idea of their children reading books in which the grown-ups are so consistently portrayed as stupid, cruel, and out of touch with the really important things in life. His earlier work is a lot less harsh, but the attitude is basically the same: most people are cruel idiots, and the exceptional few who are not are justified in doing what they like to the many who are. Not a nice point of view, but it makes for interesting stories which -- crucially -- place the eccentric characters above the "normal" ones._Charlie and the Chocolate Factory_ was a favourite of mine as a child, chiefly for the factory itself, a creation which ranks with Wonderland as a magical realm in which reality is ever-so-slightly skewed. The film is different in many ways to the book -- what film adaptation is not? -- but it has a power all its own, derived from the hallucinogenic imagery and the witty songs as much as from Gene Wilder's absent-minded-professor performance as Wonka. The characters are slightly different, as is the plot, and Dahl reportedly hated the film, but so what? A book is not a film, and vice versa. The film's story and overall tone is faithful to the tone of Dahl's book (and, in some ways, the sequel _Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator_) and it has essentially the same moral: you can't get something for nothing, even by magic, and if you want to get you want it is sometimes necessary to think in spirals.On top of that, the film is never dull, always entertaining. I have watched it as a child and as an adult and enjoyed it more with each viewing.

Although thoroughly entertaining and one of my childhood favorites I couldn't rate this movie a ten.  A slow first half (I know, build characters) grinds to a halt with the sappy ballad sung to Charlie by Mrs. Bucket.  It takes the appearance of Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder) to get things moving again but momentum is lost a second time as the movie slows down after the "fizzy lifting drinks" scene.  The middle third of the film, though, makes everything forgiveable.  In all, a timeless movie to be enjoyed by everyone.  Best viewed as a double feature with "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang" in an evil-film-disguised-as-a-childrens-movie theme.

reviews.review_title: A good movie, but not really true to the book.
reviews.content: I was born 6 years after the movie was made. I read the book numerous of times throughout my childhood and didn't see the movie until I was 24. Knowing the book by heart I got pretty disappointed. It didn't quite follow it, and I don't know why. It's basically a very uncomplicated and short book that easily could have turned into a movie. And I just can't see why they have turned Willy Wonka from a strange but eccentric man (book) to a rambling nutcase (movie).But still. If you haven't read the book I can strongly recommend that you see this movie. A movie about dreams coming true, worlds that just exist in your imagination (and on film) and great humour. But for the real deal: Read the book. It's one of Roald Dahls best and don't forget to catch the second book (yes, there is two of them)

No else one could have pulled of the part of Wonka like Gene Wilder does- he's frightening, charming, and sad all at once. This film is not that bad but It is a horror film not a kiddie film those umpa lumpas are evil and the way the kids disappear im sure they die it is scary!!!!

Just watched it, probably the first time since becoming an adult, And I loved it as much as I did when I was a kid. Spellbinding, psychedelic, Strange(in a good way), uplifting, imaginative, witty, and guaranteed to induce munchies. Gene Wilder is outstanding as the eccentric confectioner, managing to be dry(His half hearted attempts of stopping the brats getting into trouble for instance) and compellingly odd. The Chocolate Factory itself is a low tech miracle and although the sets were obviously made on a shoestring budget it just looks right(Even the spray-gold(tm) shopping cart doesn't look outta place with a bright orange, bright green haired person of limited stature pushing it). The films musical score is on the whole energetic uplifting and catchy, with the meloncoly "Cheer up Charlie" being the exception. The film has some sinister elements to it, the main one for me was the brilliantly cast Mr Slugworth(Günter Meisner) but friends and family had their own opinions on which bits they found weird.WW&TCF has aged well and I personally feel a remake is an unnecessary step but hey what do I know it might be good but it would have to go some to be beat the original for me, but the youngungs will probably lap it up. Everybody I've got a golden ticket..la la la lala .I've got a golden ticket. KbJ

I've seen bits and pieces of this film over the years (usually only the parts in the chocolate factory, oompa loompas, etc.) and never liked any of it. Today I saw it right from the beginning, which I'd never seen before. The first part is okay - too bad they had to ruin it with the second half. For a movie made in 1971, the set and effects are terrible - the Wizard of Oz is more believable and that was made in 1939! The chocolate river looked like brown colored water - they could have done better than that, thickened it up so it looked real melted chocolate. I mean, how hard could that have been? And Gene Wilder is absolutely creepy, and the singing is horrible! The boat scene, forget it - I had to turn it off this morning, it is so stupid, along with the dumb song he sings throughout it. And the ooompa loompas - I hate them most of all. What a waste of a film, for kids and adults. I hope to never see it again.

reviews.review_title: Caramel. And Cherries. And Peanuts, oh my! Oh wait, that's a different movie.
reviews.content: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory has long been one of my all time favorites when it comes to children movies. The more I think about it, though, the more clear it becomes to think that this movie isn't only for the youngsters, but adults and teenagers alike. The humor that melts off of every single action and event, the zaniness of the story, the setting for which the film takes place in... all of it adds up to a movie that the whole family can enjoy. The book that this movie was based off of, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is also a favorite of mine, if not because Roald Dahl wrote it. That brings me to one of my biggest reasons why this movie was such a hit success: the man truly behind the story was not necessarily the director, but Dahl, who made up from scratch every nook and cranny you see. He also wrote the screenplay, as a matter of fact. From the almost loony Willy Wonka - - played perfectly by none other than the legendary Gene Wilder - - to the chocolate factory itself, it's hard not to take notice and admit that Mr. Dahl played an important role in the movies glory.So let's get down to the meat of the movie, shall we? The lead character of our story is a young boy by the name of Charlie Bucket (played by the talented Peter Ostrum) who lives in a lower-class neighborhood alongside his Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson) and several other ailing family members. Sweeping into town comes an announcement from behind the doors of a mysterious chocolate factory: five lucky children will have a chance to get a tour of the also mystical Willy Wonka's factory! The chase is on, and all chocolate factories from one end of the street to another are jam-packed of kids wanting to find the lucky golden ticket that holds the "key" to the tour. Before anyone knows what's happened, four kids have got their tickets. Sadly, all of them are spoiled rotten brats. This pattern changes when Charlie finds the final ticket, and he's ecstatic. Bringing along Grandpa Joe, Charlie embarks on the tour with high hopes. What he gets is more than a little unexpected, I'm sure.I can't help but take notice of the amazingly beautiful background that this film is saturated in. Yes, perhaps they are dated, but for a movie that was filmed in the early 1970's, the producers and what not did a superb job of making the whole "fantasy candy land" a reality, and I applaud them sincerely. I actually think it's better that this movie is so old, as it gives it a very surreal aura. I also cannot forget the acting! Throughout the movie I found myself honestly intrigued with every character that was thrown my way. Every actor made their persona as believable as possible, especially Gene Wilder who I have to tip my hat to. I first saw the man in Young Frankenstein, and he never ceases to surprise me with his unbelievable top-botch portrayal of zany characters. His job as Willy Wonka is no exception.Willy Wonka is a part of pop culture, it would seem. It's hard not to notice the effect that it's had on the States. Whether it's constant references to people turning into blueberries, the constant jokes about Oompa Loompa's, the memorable Marilyn Manson video where he imitates one of my favorite scenes in the movie... it all gives more reason to check this movie out. As I said before, this is a total family movie. Not just confined to the age-old "child" or "adult" categories, Willy Wonka crosses the border and becomes a classic that no one will forget any time soon. Check this one out now for good laughs, an intriguingly eccentric story and character line-up, and extraordinary acting to boot.

This is MY favorite movie of all time. It just has a magical feel to it. Peter Ostrum should have at least been nominated for an Oscar for his performance! Was it really a stretch for George C. Scott? He really came across as an innocent, wanting a better life for his family. If Haley Joel Osment could be nominated for the Sixth Sense (yes he was very good), so should Peter. Can anyone say Honorary Oscar? I think it may be time we got a grass roots movement together to get this guy some kind of recognition for his acting. My particular favorite, and most touching moment is when he and his grandfather open the candy bar while everyone is sleeping, no golden ticket. His response..."I bet it makes the chocolate taste terrible"...Remember this was his first and ONLY movie.

reviews.review_title: Candy for the Eyes and Ears
reviews.content: Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory is the story of an eccentric owner of a candy company named Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder) who holds a contest to find five golden tickets in his candy bars. Whoever finds them will be allowed to enter his factory. Amongst the winners is an average boy named Charlie. Charlie and others are led by Willy Wonka through a world of imagination and wonder.This is absolutely one of the greatest children's movies ever created. Not only does it please the eyes with its fantasy world full of imagination and vibrant colors, it contains great songs that you will be singing for a weeks to come. Gene Wilder portrays Willy Wonka brilliantly by being crazy and unpredictable. This is a must see for anyone looking for a movie that is both entertaining and fun.

reviews.review_title: Oompa Loompa doompaty do, I've got a pleasant comment or two!
reviews.content: Who can take a movie, fill it with unknowns, create a kiddies' masterpiece and make a legend? Mel Stuart can.The Chocolate Factory---every kid's dream.  Well, mine too.  This film is a sugary sweet, pure delight just like Wonka would create in his rather unusual factory.The visuals of this 1971 masterpiece are just amazing, pretty neat special effects for its' time.  Besides, is there ANY other children's movie where you can witness a chicken's head being chopped off?Now, don't go running into the living room and shut off Junior's videotape! It's fun for the whole family!  And what's more, there are literary references that can be explained to the kids and make them more well-rounded!The music numbers are ones you'll remember for a long time, catchy snappy ones written by Leslie Bricusse and Anthony Newley.  "The Candy Man" made Sammy Davis, Jr. famous!If only all kids movies could be this smart, and not play down to kids as if they were drones of society!Gene Wilder ends the movie with his line: Such a good deed in a weary world. My good deed was to write this review, so when you're weary, pop in Willy Wonka.  It's a sweet treat without making that trip to the convenience store!

reviews.review_title: A film not without flaws, but fantastic nonetheless
reviews.content: The film "Willy Wonka and the Chocalate Factory" has divided critics and moviegoers alike since it was first released. Doubtless there are some who would not enjoy this movie, as with any movie, but it is certainly among the best kids movies ever made, that is also enjoyable for adults. The film deals with a boys journey through the chocolate factory of the eccentric Mr Willy Wonka. It is an adaptation of a novel by acclaimed children's author Roald Dahl, and as such, the plot is whimsical and engrossing. I have no complaints with the plot, except for Charlie visiting his mother at the laundry, an intrusive device to allow the inclusion of a song that is boring at best. The song was supposed to give some emotional impact, and give us a look into the relationship between Charlie and his mother. The only thing this achieves, is to leave the viewer wondering why Charlie did not even consider asking his mother to accompany him to the chocolate factory, instead of his bedridden (and lazy) grandfather. Aside from this small complaint, I believe the plot is excellent.The casting of the film is superb, leading to some great acting. The obvious standout is Mr Gene Wilder, who gives the performance of his lifetime as Willy Wonka. He is charming, eccentric, dark and a little bit scary. Of course no small amount of this is due to a script that gives him some great lines. Still, we must take nothing away from Gene Wilder, who gives a performance that most actors would give their right arms to equal. Other characters are also memorable, such as; Charlie's teacher, Veruca, Veruca's father, Violet, Mr Slugworth and the candy store owner. All of the actors playing these parts give exceptional performances. In regards to the characters, the only real complaint is Charlie himself. He is noticeably the weakest link in the chain. This is not entirely the actors fault, though he must shoulder some of the blame. The character, as written, is weak. He is given nothing memorable to say or do. He seems to be your classic goody-two-shoes (despite the "fizzy lifting drink" episode, obviously added to try and combat this problem). Charlie is supposed to be the "straight" character, in that he is the normal one. This is to give the other characters someone to "bounce off" if you will. However this idea was carried much to far, to the detriment of the film. Such is the problem that every second Charlie is on screen, we wish for the camera to focus on a different character. Other than this, the characters, and acting, are great.It may seem that this review is rather critical given the rating (10/10). This rating was given in response to the amount of enjoyment that one can get from watching this film. The movie is flawed, yet it is a great movie nonetheless. No movie is perfect, despite what some fans might say. But a great movie is enjoyable in spite of its flaws. This is a must see movie. Please, before seeing the new Tim Burton version, watch Mel Stuart's version, as it is one of the great films.

Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory is possibly one of the last pure hearted movies created in our time.  So many others are filled with perversion or violence it's difficult for one to simply sit back and enjoy the movie. The film features a small boy who lives in impoverished conditions and because of his deepest desires wins and opportunity to visit the famed `Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory'.  The movie points out very valuable lessons for children and adults alike.  Avoid the snares of greed and dishonesty. Avoid the mind rotting affects of watching too much television.  But of course the most monumental lesson in this movie is that the pure of heart are rewarded in the end.If you haven't seen this movie, I can only ask this one question `What are you waiting for?'

reviews.review_title: Wonderful film from a great author
reviews.content: Author of stories like 'The BFG', 'The Witches' and 'Matilda', Dahl's stories have given joy to children for a long time now. With so many of his stories being made into films, it's not difficult to see that Hollywood loves him too. In 1971, one of his finest stories was made into a musical starring Gene Wilder. Magnificantly 'odd', Wilder's Willy Wonka is a genuinely surreal performance. Twenty years on, and an inferior sequel later, and Wilder is still the way to go. The film might be dated, but with a Wonka like this, it's impossible not to fall in love with the film again.Charlie Bucket's (Peter Ostrum) family are incredibly poor. Living with his mum and four grandparents, Charlie dreams of better things. When the mysterious Willy Wonka (Wilder) announces that five lucky children will be allowed to tour his chocolate factory, Charlie has a dream. Receiving one chocolate bar on his birthday however, the odds are stacked against him. Still, this is a fairy tale, so you can imagine what's coming next.Filmed in Eastern Europe and with five children paid on the cheap, 'Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory' is full of legends on screen and off. Colourful and beautiful throughout, it possesses many amazing scenes.As far as children performers go, the three kids do an alright job. Ostrum and Julie Dawn Cole (playing the greedy Veruca Salt) in particular are singled out for praise as they jump, run, sing and perform for the camera at every possibility. Ultimately though, the children will always be overshadowed by Gene Wilder.Wilder takes insanity to a new level. One moment seeming totally normal, and the next randomly talking and singing to himself, Wilder's Wonka is a man on the edge. You watch him and you just know that he could win your heart whilst simultaneously scare you senseless. You certainly have to wonder what Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson) is thinking when Wonka hugs Charlie towards the end. Ultimately though, however nuts Wilder is in this film, it is him who makes it watchable so many years later.

When I first saw this movie in 1979 aged 9, I found it terrifying but at the same time it became one of my all-time favourites from my childhood. It's the ultimate children's fantasy story, but it's not all fun and games: it sends out a strong message which would be particularly poignant in today's society.And a warning: make sure you have a few boxes of Kleenex handy for the very last line in the movie - it's a killer. I'm getting choked up just thinking about it!

reviews.review_title: "A little nonsense now and then, is relished by the wisest men."

For adults there is a rich vein of humour.They cleverly shot it in Bavarian Germany with a mix of American and British actors, which makes the story feel like it could be anywhere.Gene Wilder puts on an unforgettably mesmerizing performance and Roy Kinnear makes a very good exasperated straight man to his zaniness.

The songs are all brilliant(except maybe "Cheer up Charlie" which is OK in moderation but gets a little tiring after a while)I mean, come on, "Pure Imagination", "I've got a golden ticket" Verruca Salt singing "I want it now", and obviously, "The Candyman". And no matter what anyone says, I love the boat scene. i know the special effects are crap(none of them get splashed, their hair isn't even blown back!) but Gene Wilder's weird spur-of-the-moment song sends shivers down my spine. (He's the best actor EVER!!)Overall, i would say, go buy this classic movie. Now! Go on! You're not gone yet! What are you waiting for? you heard Gene Wilder's in it, right?? GO!

reviews.review_title: wickedly funny, doesn't pander to kids
reviews.content: Wicked irony, dark humor, and truckloads of wordplay - not things you ordinarily find in children's movies.  This film comes about 90% of the way to the sparkle of the book.Roald Dahl's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" was one of those rare pieces of children's literature that didn't pander to its audience - no soft, safe goody-two-shoes story, but rather a rich, wry, giddy whirl, full of barbs and gleeful prankery.  The film (retitled for the main character) gets about as close to Dahl's manic irony as a children's movie has ever come or is ever likely to.  I can almost picture a young Tim Burton watching it over and over.  (For some examples of less-successful stabs at bringing Dahl's children's work to the screen, see "Matilda" and "James and the Giant Peach.")It's too bad they don't make them like this any more.  I enjoyed it as a child because it had wit and cunning, and managed to be moral without preaching (which seems to be beyond the capabilities of today's children's filmmakers).  I enjoy it even more as an adult just to revel in its delightful edginess and smile at the puns and wordplay.I have this to say to those worrywarts who wring their hands and natter about this film supposedly causing psychological damage to kids: get a life. Children are not fragile little soap bubbles that will burst at the touch of a sharp wit, unless you make them that way.  They're people too, and they can appreciate cleverness when they see it.  Let them.

I love this film, possibly because I have a three year old who becomes totally absorbed in the story whenever he sees it. I've rediscovered the eye-popping delights of a secret world dedicated to the guilt-free invention and sampling of scrumptious chocolate and sugar confections. It's a cautionary tale of course - a concept my son has yet to grasp, bless him - warning against the evils of excess and over-indulgence and celebrating virtue and honesty. I love the three main characters - they all play their roles to perfection, particularly Gene Wilder who was just perfect casting. His Willy Wonka is, naturally, a reclusive oddball who, in the course of the factory tour, proves to be an intriguing combination of secretive, controlling, unpredictable grown-up and candid, excitable, mischievous, capricious child. Dated special-effects and appalling singing included, this film is a joy from start to finish. The saccharine ending is the icing on the cake.

But no matter what becomes of that possibility, nothing will EVER hold a candle to this classic original. For heaven's sake -- it's like trying to remake "Gone With The Wind"!

reviews.review_title: "Traveling in a world of my creation"
reviews.content: When I sit down to watch a movie I want to be transported someplace else and I want to walk away feeling SOMETHING. When I sat down to watch 'Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory' (after many years of not seeing it) I still loved it, I still felt happy at the end and I still believed that there was that golden ticket out there for the taking. The viewer is carried away into a world where good is rewarded and evil is punished (or sent down a garbage chute!). In the end you walk away feeling that good begets good and all is right in the world...if only through the course of the film.Even though the film was made in 1971 it is not dated and the effects hold up. Gene Wilder plays a quirky chocolatier who randomly slips into the erratic but guides five children into a world of pure imagination. His performance is infallible and unfaltering. Along the way the viewer is able to see what behavior is unacceptable, thanks to the Oompa Loompa's musical morality. The film does leave some questions unanswered. The most glaring being where are Charlie's parents? If you as the viewer can dismiss reality and all logical explanation for just a few hours...you're in for a wild ride.The sign of a "classic" film is one that holds up through time. This movie is perfect for families needing a night's entertainment. The same is true for adults wanting to recapture the first time they stepped through the doors of the mystical factory, golden ticket in hand. David Seltzer was able to take the basic premise of Roald Dahl's book and create a timeless screenplay that transcends the years. He may have digressed but the end result is a movie that many generations can view and still enjoy with bright-eyed innocence.

Superb synthesis, for children & adults, one of those rare movies that lives up to the book. The scene that should not be missed is the boat ride & song. If the opportunity to see it in a theater should arise DO NOT PASS IT UP! Roald Dahl is one of my favorite authors & I highly recommend any & all of his books, especially "The Wonderful Story Of Henry Sugar & 6 More"(not for young children). If you know a child (or adult) who does not like to read, Mr. Dahl will change their mind.

At any rate, Willy Wonka is a tremendously imaginative and inspiring film. It's a family film, but one of the most important aspects of a family film is that it has to be enjoyable for a variety of ages. This is what makes movies like Toy Story and Shrek such huge successes- the adults will love it just as much as the kids are sure to. Hence: 'family' film. On the other hand, this is also the downfall of such other movies that are strictly for a much younger audience, like Cats & Dogs. The makers of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory understood this very well, and you can see that just by the way that the cast is divided. Here are all of these kids (funny how it was only kids who found those golden tickets) who were at this candy factory, and they had each elected to bring one of their parents with them as the one admissible member of their family who was allowed by Wonka to accompany them to the factory.One of the best elements of this film is the excellently written script and, even more, the songs. These are some of the best songs in any movie ever made, rivaling even the best of the songs from Disney's films (hey, some of them are really good). There are, of course, some exceptions, such as 'Cheer up, Charlie,' which I have been fast-forwarding through for as long as I can remember, but for the most part, the songs are fun to listen to and they pertain to life outside the movie. They are not just songs about the candy-making genius of Willy Wonka or the excitement of being able to tour his mysterious factory, but they are about life in the real world. They're about believing in yourself and being motivated in life ('Anything you want to, do it. Want to change the world, there's nothing to it'), but there are also some that have to do mostly with the movie but are still just as enjoyable, such as the classic song that Wonka sings in the tunnel on board his boat (curiously named 'Wonkatania'), which was creepily covered by Marilyn Manson a couple of decades later.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is an everlasting movie, one that exudes surrealism in every frame; yet it is so human it's hard to imagine a world without little green men that make chocolate and sing morals. Please watch this movie again if you found it frightening, confusing, or dull when you were a child, it's really not for kids.

Willy Wonka is a strange man, not much is known about him other than running a chocolate factory, but as the story progresses we find out more and more information about who this guy really is.

When Gene Wilder died there was quiet grief that shook fans everywhere. Willy Wonka is one of those legendary roles and Gene Wilder brought the character to life. Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory was released 52 years ago and hasn't aged a day. There's something primal about the story of Charlie Bucket going on the hero's journey. It's what Dan Harmon describes as "an endlessly entertaining myth that's really just satisfying on the level of Jack and the Beanstalk or Ulysses fighting a cyclops." 

For many of us kids, we loved Gene Wilder and his Wonka adventures since we were first able to love things. It's a fondness that runs deep. Wonka is a unique character. It's easy to relate to an underdog like Charlie but Wonka is who we want to be. Whatever his troubled past, Wonka made it to the other side. He's a self-made and successful business owner who runs a candy factory. 

How does Wonka do it? Winkelmann says, "How do fish swim? How do birds fly? They do it because they were born to do it. Just like Willy Wonka was born to be a candy man." That passion is contagious and admirable. Wonka is a big kid. He wears a purple coat, brown top hat, and large bow tie. He's often cynical and fights against his anger, but he's also optimistic, sentimental, and hopeful. He feels everything. He's broken but there's a humanity beneath the surface.

Willy Wonka follows the Joseph Campbell myth. It's a traditional story that is well told and faithfully executed. Based on the 1964 book by Roald Dahl, Willy Wonka is thematically rich. Dahl is a legend for any anglophile. His work has been adapted by many filmmakers including Steven Spielberg. Dahl's life was plagued with joy and tragedy. Many of Dahl's characters are orphans and Charlie Bucket has no father or siblings. The character of Willy Wonka is based on Edward Cadbury of the Cadbury chocolate company. Cadbury produced everything from chocolate bars to the Turkish delight featured in The Chronicles of Narnia.

When Dahl was a child in the 1920s, chocolate ceased to be a luxury product and became affordable to the working class. During the war, the British government encouraged chocolate production like the US government encouraged cheese. There was a lot available and everyone ate it. For Dahl, chocolate was escapism. Dahl's stories always had a combination of sorrow and joy, tragedy and triumph. But there was always a prevailing optimism and childlike wonder.

Willy Wonka is about five kids who get a Golden Ticket and the chance to tour the chocolate factory. The tour is really a test as Wonka is looking for an apprentice to take over. All the kids have a fatal flaw or a bad habit. Augustus Gloop is a glutton, Veruca Salt is spoiled, Mike Teevee watches too much TV, and Violet Beauregarde chews gum. In addition, each kid is tempted by Slugworth to steal an Everlasting Gobstopper in exchange for money. But Charlie is pure of heart.

Wonka instructs, "Now remember, no messing about. No touching, no tasting, no telling." If anyone disobeys the rules, he or she is disqualified from winning a lifetime supply of candy. These rules are impossible to keep and every kid falls short. No one deserves to win. But unlike the other kids who get eliminated by their own choices, it's Grandpa Joe who offers Charlie the Fizzy Lifting drink which causes him to break the rules. 

Wonka sees this and lets it slide for the moment. Even the Tunnel of Terror is a test where the passengers are shown distributing images. Wonka wants to see who will crack first. Charlie and Grandpa Joe remain calm until Wonka starts his sadistic poem. Wonka makes every question a quiz, every choice a test. Charlie is judged in relation to the other kids and in the end, he is morally exceptional. 

Upset with Wonka's legalism, Grandpa Joe wants to give the gobstopper to Slugworth but Charlie refuses. There's a line Charlie won't cross. Charlie cares for Wonka like a child does a father. It seems to be destiny that the fatherless Charlie and the childless Wonka are brought together. Charlie has a Wonka size hole in his heart that can't be filled with money and moon pies. Wonka sees that Charlie was raised right and says that his entire family can move in with him. 

The Oompa Loompas agree with the bad parent philosophy, "Blaming the kids is a lie and a shame / You know exactly who's to blame? / The mother and the father." Charlie's surrogate family is made whole. Wonka is like Carnegie, Ford, and Gates. His factory is made possible through Capitalism. To paraphrase Wonka, "If you want to view paradise, simply look around and view it. Anything you want to do - do it." Wonka knows what he wants, goes after at, and lives are changed because of it. 

Charlie and his destitute family are pulled out of poverty by Wonka. And Charlie wasn't rewarded for free. He had to earn his place at the table or he wouldn't appreciate it. Early in the story, Charlie has a paper route. He's the only kid in the group that is seen working. He's also the most generous of the five kids. Charlie is anxious to share with others and kind to everyone.

Willy Wonka rests of the very capable shoulders of Gene Wilder. He's a staple of childhood and an iconic performer. No one else could embody the zany, joyous, lunatic, but calculated energy like Wilder. The film just doesn't work without Gene. Director Mel Stuart is the cousin of Stan Lee so it's clear that Pure Imagination runs in the family. The collaboration of Wilder, Stuart, and Dahl is one for the books. 

The music by Bricusse, Newley, and Scharf is some of best in film history. They are the music makers. They are the dreamers of dreams. Wonka the man has childhood hurts that need healing and his arrested development is relatable to a young audience. Nerdist writer Michael Walsh said it well, "Willy Wonka didn't fail the world, it failed him. The world can seem dark and disappointing, but it isn't. There is always hope, a humanity that will overcome, and it was Gene Wilder who brought that to life."

This is a hugely enjoyable film, based upon the book by Roald Dahl. The film does have a number of merits, especially the flawless performance of Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka, a characterisation that is charming and funny at the same time. Another standout is Jack Albertson as Grandpa Joe, his scenes with Charlie were lovingly realised, but in his song, he was just hilarious, and his singing voice was remarkably good. However, whereas Peter Ostrum is perfectly agreeable in terms of acting as Charlie, he is let down by his lack of any real singing ability. Though the film does look beautiful with excellent cinematography and colourful sets, and the supporting characters like the Oompa Loompas, the odiously spoilt Veruca Salt, television addict Mike Tevee and the rather disgusting Violet Bueragarde, are very well done, and the actors are further advantaged by a wonderful sparkling script. The songs are lovely, especially Oompa Loompa, Imagination and I want it Now, though I will say I felt Cheer Up Charlie was rather tedious and slowed the film down quite considerably. Overall, a beautiful film, and I do think it is underrated. 8/10 Bethany Cox.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, directed by Mel Stuart, was a very fun & colorful adaptation to Roald Dahl's story. With this movie being made in the early 70's, it still holds up for the most part, almost grasping that classic title. Stuart & Dahl put a lot of heart into this film, giving the audience a pure, heartfelt message. The narrative is very creative & unique, while having some strange & over the top moments that were hit or miss. The first act made for a solid one, introducing these odd but fun characters, but it could've been cut down maybe by ten minutes, allowing the second act to have just that much more time to shine.

The cast of the fim put on great performances across the board, but Gene Wilder absolutely stole the show! This was such a trademark casting, where even the best actors today couldn't recapture his character. Peter Ostrum as Charlie did a very good job! He put on a great performance, where you really cared for him and his struggles from the first minute. Jack Albertson was another enjoyable addition to the film, adding great mature nature to the film, with an enjoyable hint of playfulness. The golden ticket finders and their parents all stood out in their own way, and were all around a load of fun. They're not characters you can really invest into, but they're great additions nevertheless.

The screenplay was real charming, with a sweet & sour twist to it. The production design was real colorful a beautifully crafted, along with a FANTASTIC & catchy soundtrack to fit this fun movie.

Overall, this movie had some room for improvement, maybe not holding up the best after almost a whopping 50 years, but this is definitely something you need to see before you die !

Director Mel Stuart's family fantasy film Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (1971) is a timeless classic as it is always delightful at all ages. Stuart's craftsmanship is undeniable with clever shots of candy, faces, and eyes that convey a sense of wonder and expression. 

Willy Wonka is a hilarious satire on the depravity society undergoes for social acceptance and financial freedom. This film takes on class struggle, British education, media coverage, shoddy journalism, excessive capitalism, corrupt business practices, and above all, bad parenting. You will laugh at something new every year you go back and watch Willy Wonka.

There is even a few horror elements as these children and their chosen immediate family members undergo a haunted house disguised as a candy themed fun house. The children are competing for a lifetime supply of chocolate, so they are whittled down to one as they disappear. The boat sequence with spliced in edits of gruesome or creepy imagery is meant to unnerve you and scarred an entire generation of kids that watched Willy Wonka. Facing disappointment and defeat is another interesting lesson Willy Wonka teaches young Charlie, but thankfully he is such a sympathetic and selfless character he wins by virtue of his decency. Charlie has only ever cared for others and desired something of his own, thus Wonka finds him worthy to inherit his magnificent chocolate factory.

The family drama is heartwarming as we follow the likable lead from a desolate environment of abject poverty into a sustainable future of happiness and success. Charlie Bucket is wonderfully played by Peter Ostrum, who is the most pathetic and destitute Charlie Bucket imaginable. His misfortune is all brought on him by his low birth, but the reason you empathize and sympathize with him is that he'e righteous good, selfless care, and random luck personified. Ostrum captures a childlike wonder of the impossible and magic that enthralls you to the end of his sweet story.

Likewise, Gene Wilder steals the show as the eccentric and entertaining candy inventor Willy Wonka! Wilder carries himself with a confident, likable grandeur and a charming facade for Willy Wonka to hypnotize you with constant wonders, misdirection, and advice. Wilder's singing during Willy Wonka's signature song "Pure Imagination" is iconic and lovely. His character clearly loathes the bad kids and desperately wants to find a pearl among the swines. Wilder's sly smile and quirky persona make for an unforgettable Willy Wonka like no other could ever replicate. Wilder's dramatic performance in Wonka's half office is gripping, scary, heartwarming, and life changing as he goes through so many emotions in the span of a few seconds. Gene Wilder was a gifted actor able to captivate you with his cunning dramatic skill and delight you with rousing charismatic comedy. 

Wilder is funny giving cruel commentary as children are taken away by his wondrous little workers the Oompa Loompas. These little people are delightful with their luminescent green hair, dyed orange skin, white overalls, and goofy dances. I adore their parable songs that teach each lesson to the audience after each bad egg among the cast's batch gets theirs. They teach excellent lessons warning against indulging greed, consuming gluttony, being rude, watching too much television, and spoiling your children. Jack Albertson is fantastic as the morally curious Grandpa Joe character, who wants the best for his grandson Charlie. I really like Charlie's sad mother Diana Sowle, who is just trying to give Charlie a decent life through her clothes washing job.

Furthermore, I like how Wonka's mystique is established early, so that you are curious about this hidden candy man shrouded in mystery and intrigue. Especially as you realize quickly, Wonka just wants to punish the wicked children for their bad morals, while rewarding the innocent and kindly chosen child. A sweet kid could surely be the only winner of a candy factory for Willy Wonka.

As for the bad children, the child cast is filled with apt casting of the most reprehensible and annoying deviants adolescence has ever conceived of on film. Julie Dawn Cole is the monstrous spoiled rich girl Veruca Salt. Her screaming, whining, and complaining is hilarious and fits her character perfectly. She is a great singer during her number in the golden goose room. Denise Nickerson is excellent as the constantly chewing Violet Beauregarde. She is annoying in her overly confident persona, which is perfect for this insistent child horror. Paris Themmen is crazy obnoxious as the know-it-all Mike Teavee, who worships the entertainment box too much. Michael Bollner plays the rotund glutton Augustus Gloop with a dour hunger for all sweets.

For me, Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory will always remain a timeless classic for the cinema world that enchants with a vision of the world that can progress and change for the better. Remember to be yourself, be kind, and use your imagination!

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is about the genius, Willy Wonka reopening his mysterious chocolate factory. Wonka puts out 5 golden tickets in his chocolate bars in search for 5 lucky people, each person can bring along one guest. The 5 chosen ones get a lifetime supply of chocolate and a tour of Wonka's factory. Charlie Bucket, an adolescent who comes from a poor family dreams of getting one of the 5 golden tickets. Luck strikes him and he gets the last and final golden ticket. He picks Grandpa Joe as his guest. Once the tour begins, every child except for Charlie gets into unfortunate accidents and is forced to leave the tour. Charlie and Grandpa Joe sneaks out of the tour and drinks forbidden products without permission. Once the tour was over, Wonka ignores Charlie and soon tells him why: he drank forbidden product. Grandpa Joe insists on telling Arthur Slugworth the formula to the everlasting gobstopper, but Charlie returns it instead. Willy Wonka sees the kindness in Charlie's heart and Charlie's family lived happily ever after.

I read the book (by Roald Dahl) to the kids and they were very taken by its wonders and its humour (and I hoped that its morality tale would sink in).  Therefore, I was curious to see how they felt about the movie version (the one from my childhood, not the later Johnny Depp remake) which I recalled fondly, despite some vivid early nightmares featuring Oompa Loompas.  I worried a bit that the movie's images might come to dominate what they saw with their own imaginations but it seems not to be the case -- the kids voted for the book over the movie.  But perhaps that is always what happens when you read a book first?  To recap, little Charlie Bucket longs for a golden ticket that will give him a tour of Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory and a lifetime's supply of sweets - but there are only five such tickets in the world, hidden underneath the wrappers of Wonka chocolate bars.  Of course, after suspense is built, Charlie does find a ticket and he and his Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson) are taken on a magical and sometimes scary tour of the factory by Mr. Willy Wonka himself, played with a serene sense of perfect ambivalence by Gene Wilder.  Wilder is easily the best thing about the movie, giving exquisite line readings (whether absurd or menacing or bemused), although the various rooms in the factory do have a candy-coated funhouse charm to them.  Surprisingly, the film didn't seem childish or particularly dated, although the haze of nostalgia might be clouding my judgment.  I had forgotten however that this was a musical (apart from the scary songs sung by the Oompa Loompas after the bad children are dispatched with) and the various songs (including "Candy Man") work to bring out the fantasy elements of the film.   Of course, the book didn't have the songs and some of the episodes are different (squirrels not golden geese, for example).  Most significantly, Charlie and Grandpa Joe don't break the rules in the book.  However, this twist does add more suspense to the film than the book and gives Wilder a chance to turn Charlie's grim disappointment into ecstatic amazement, something that every child (and adult) deserves to feel at least once.

As an adult though the first half in particular is really funny.  Wilder has never been better on screen and you feel it really stays true to the twisted spirit of the Roald Dahl original.  Obviously light years ahead of the Johnny Depp travesty remake.

Definitely one of a kind, due to it's adamant surrealism, it appeals to both kids and adults.

The elusive Wonka chocolate factory is holding a worldwide contest so that 5 lucky winners can finally get a glimpse inside the factory walls and win a lifetime supply of chocolate.

It's supposed to take place in America, but maintains an industrial European feel. Charlie Bucket, our protagonist, lives with his mother and 4 grandparents. They're very poor, and rely on Charlie's paper route money to get by. Which is why Charlie wants, more than anything, to win this contest. 

Anyone who's ever known they wanted something more than anyone else in the world can relate to Charlie's childlike desire to win Wonka's contest. It may seem frivolous, but that only highlights Charlie's desperation. He can only imagine luxurious things. And that ingenuous mindset is what just may give him what he needs.

The film enraptures you within the first 35 minutes, before we even get inside the magical factory. And once we're in, the film ascends to a whole new level. So full of unique ideas and concepts. Set pieces that made people depressed about the movie's fictionality long before Avatar's ever did.

And Willy Wonka, himself, portrayed by Gene Wilder, is a marvel. No other man could have given us such a brilliant performance. He's sweet, he's creepy, he's sincere, and he's mischievous. Roald Dahl's original 1964 novel could be adapted for film one thousand times over, yet Wilder will always remain exclusively synonymous with the role.

Oh yeah, and the music is phenomenally perfect.

For being a "flop" from 1971, this film holds up better than most, if not all, of its contemporaries.

When I heard the news of Gene Wilder's passing, I immediately thought of his portrayal of Willy Wonka in Mel Stuart's Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (1971), which is the film adaptation of Roald Dahl's 1964 novel Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Wilder plays the mysterious and genius candy maker Willy Wonka, who has become a recluse from society and hides inside his chocolate factory. Although he has long banned workers from going into and out of his factory, his delicious and creative chocolates as well as other exotic candies keep on coming out. As such, he and his candies have become stuff of legend. In the film, he has finally decided to reopen and allow outsiders to enter and tour his factory. The catch is that only five people and an accompanying guest will be allowed the great honor. In a brilliant method to randomly select those individuals, he has placed five Golden Tickets in five random candy bars. The lucky people that find the tickets will be granted entry into the factory and receive a lifetime supply of chocolate. The story follows the young and selfless Charlie Bucket who hopelessly dreams of defying the odds and finding one of the tickets. Of course, he does it and we follow him, four other children, and their adult chaperones as they explore the fantastic and surreal yet dangerous factory of Willy Wonka. Interestingly, the movie was a flop when it was first released in 1971. However, its popularity increased in the mid-1980s due to television broadcasts and home video sales. Retrospectively, it has become one of the most beloved children's movies and is critically acclaimed. I remember it fondly as part of my childhood. It is one of the few stories I remember vividly despite not having watched it in a very long time [until I watched it again after Wilder's death]. As a comparison, I had watched the remake, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (2005) starring Johnny Deep as Willy Wonka, much more recently; I barely remember anything about it. For me and many fans, the original film is the official film adaptation and the only one we recognize. Although the book is focused on Charlie as the main character, Wilder's Willy Wonka is clearly the dominant character in the original film adaptation. As Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory became a cult film, Wilder's Willy Wonka became an iconic role that defines his career. It is a great children's movie because it challenges the limits of imagination with the impossible wonders inside Wonka's factory, encourages good behavior while strongly discourages poor vices for kids, and features memorable musical numbers. On the other hand, the film and especially Wonka also display some very dark, sadistic undertones that I did not really understand when I was younger. Now that I am an adult, the incredible contrasts make a look back at the movie extremely interesting.
